meanings.definition: used to express satisfaction that something bad has happened to someone who deserved it, or to show that you have succeeded in something:

meanings.definition: used to express surprise, interest, or victory:

meanings.definition: an expression used to make another person feel silly, often showing pleasure at your own success or their failure, or showing that you do not think something is funny:
examples: Ha ha, you fell over.

meanings.definition: a ditch (= a long, narrow, open hole) with a wall inside it that you cannot see from ground level, that forms the edge of a garden or park without blocking the view:
examples: At the edge of the garden, a ha-ha allows you to look directly out over the outer park and its fine trees.

a cold mist coming from the sea to the east of Scotland or northern England:

meanings.definition: a type of small, orange, very hot-tasting chilli that is often used in Latin American cooking:

meanings.definition: a legal order that states that a person in prison must appear before and be judged by a court of law before he or she can be forced by law to stay in prison
a legal action demanding that a prisoner be brought before a judge to make sure that he or she is not being held illegally

meanings.definition: someone whose job is selling cloth, pins, thread, etc. used for sewing, or a shop where these things are sold
someone whose job is selling clothing for men, or a shop where clothing for men is sold
cloth, pins, thread, etc. used for sewing, or a shop or a department of a large store that sells these
clothing for men, or a shop or department in a large store that sells this
something that you do often and regularly, sometimes without knowing that you are doing it:
examples: I always buy the same brand of toothpaste out of (= because of) habit.
I'm trying not to get into (= start) the habit of always having biscuits with my coffee.
I used to swim twice a week, but I seem to have got out of (= ended) the habit recently.

I'm not really in the habit of looking at (= I don't usually look at) other people's clothes, but even I noticed that awful suit!

meanings.definition: something annoying that someone often does:

meanings.definition: a strong physical need to keep taking a particular drug:

meanings.definition: a special piece of long clothing worn by monks and nuns
a particular act or way of acting that you tend to do regularly:

meanings.definition: usual or repeated:

meanings.definition: usual or repeated:

meanings.definition: in a way that is habitual (= usual for someone or often repeated):

meanings.definition: to get used to something or to make someone or something used to something:

meanings.definition: to cut into pieces in a rough and violent way, often without aiming exactly:
examples: Three villagers were hacked to death in a savage attack.

meanings.definition: in football, to foul (= act against the rules) by kicking another player in the leg in a violent way:
examples: He was twice hacked down in the second half by the other team's sweeper.

meanings.definition: in rugby, to kick the ball when it is loose on the ground:
examples: The scrum-half hacked the ball through for the winger to run on to.

meanings.definition: to hit at a golf ball in a rough and violent way, often without aiming exactly:

meanings.definition: to get into someone else's computer system without permission in order to find out information or do something illegal:

meanings.definition: to use someone else's phone system without permission, especially to listen to their spoken messages:

meanings.definition: to buy and sell goods:
examples: We only handle cosmetics which have not been tested on animals.

meanings.definition: to move or store goods:
examples: The distribution company handles around 45 per cent of all the milk produced in the UK.
He admitted handling stolen goods.

meanings.definition: to use your hands to move or hold something:
examples: Staff are trained and equipped to handle hazardous materials.

meanings.definition: a bar with a curved end that you hold when riding a bicycle or motorcycle and use to turn the front wheel so that it points in a different direction:
examples: He was hunched over the handlebars, pedalling furiously.
You make a turn by twisting the left handlebar.

meanings.definition: a thick, wide moustache with curled ends in the shape of handlebars
a thick, wide mustache with curled ends in the shape of handlebars
the bar along the front of a bicycle or motorcycle that a rider holds in order to balance and turn

past simple and past participle of 
        
         handle
to deal with, have responsibility for, or be in charge of:
examples: I thought he handled the situation very well.
Some people are brilliant with computers, but have no idea how to handle (= behave with) other people.
If you can't handle the job I'll get someone else to do it.
Who handles the marketing in your company?

meanings.definition: to pick something up and touch, hold, or move it with your hands:
examples: Always wash your hands before handling food.
Please don't handle the vases - they're very fragile.

meanings.definition: to operate or control something that could be difficult or dangerous:
examples: Have you ever handled a gun before?

meanings.definition: If a car handles well, it is easy and pleasant to drive.
to buy and sell goods:
examples: We only handle cosmetics that have not been tested on animals.
He's been arrested for handling stolen goods.

meanings.definition: a person who trains and is in charge of animals, especially dogs:
examples: police dog handlers

meanings.definition: someone who advises someone important:
examples: The president's handlers are telling him to pull out of the talks.

meanings.definition: someone who carries or moves things as part of their job:
examples: airport baggage handlers

meanings.definition: a person who trains and takes care of animals, esp. as a job:
examples: a dog handler

meanings.definition: a company that moves goods from one place to another:
examples: They are China's largest domestic cargo handler.

meanings.definition: someone who touches products with their hands while doing their job:
examples: The institute would like to see food handlers get more training in food safety.

meanings.definition: a person who advises or manages someone in their work, especially someone important or famous:
examples: Williams, however, is convinced Gosling and his handlers have made the wrong career move.

meanings.definition: the way that someone deals with a situation or person:
examples: President Kennedy made his reputation with his handling of the Cuban missile crisis.

meanings.definition: how easy a vehicle is to control:
examples: Power steering can dramatically improve a car's handling.

meanings.definition: the act or cost of moving, storing, or packaging goods:
examples: The company is able sell its wares for 30% less by cutting out the layers of middlemen who each tack on a charge for handling.
U.S. industry contends that segregating biotech from conventional varieties of crops would raise handling costs.

meanings.definition: the process of dealing with a situation, especially a difficult situation:
examples: His handling of economic policy has been especially bad.
careful/skillful handling

meanings.definition: the act of moving, storing, or organizing information:
examples: The inspector general's report focuses on the FBI's handling of information.

meanings.definition: a charge for dealing with an order or banking activity:
examples: Tickets are £87, plus a £2 handling charge.
The card's issuer may add a handling charge each time the card is used abroad.

meanings.definition: a charge for transporting, storing, or packaging goods:
examples: For vacuum-packed mail orders under £30, add a £3 handling charge and postage.
A special handling fee applies for Saturday pickup and delivery service.

meanings.definition: the costs of insurance, storage, transportation, etc. that are involved in buying and selling goods

→ 
        
         handling charge
made using the hands rather than a machine:
examples: handmade chocolates/paper/shoes

meanings.definition: made by a person using just hands or tools, not by a machine:
examples: handmade jewelry

meanings.definition: made by someone using their hands rather than by using a machine:
examples: Handmade products are becoming increasingly popular.

meanings.definition: a female servant
something, such as an idea, that helps and supports something else:
examples: Technique is the handmaiden of art.

meanings.definition: in American football, a pass in which the ball is put directly into the hands of another player:
examples: Flacco faked a handoff and looked to pass.
A botched handoff that was meant for him never made it to his hands.

meanings.definition: in a relay race, an occasion when a runner puts the baton into the hand of the next runner:
examples: The relay team failed to finish the final because of a botched baton handoff from Jones.

meanings.definition: in rugby, an occasion when the player carrying the ball puts the ball under one arm and pushes away a player who is trying to tackle him or her with the other hand:
examples: He swatted Smith away with a powerful handoff and galloped over the line to complete the scoring.
Watch the defender closely to see if the handoff is an option.

meanings.definition: an occasion when one person gives something to another:
examples: Drug handoffs are easy to spot.
Failure to synchronize actions during hand-offs is visible in medical settings.

meanings.definition: the act of giving control of something or responsibility for something to someone else:
examples: the handoff of power to an interim government

meanings.definition: a document given to students or reporters that contains information about a particular subject:
examples: On page two of your handout you will find a list of the books that I have referred to during the lecture.

meanings.definition: something such as food, clothing, or money that is given free to someone who has a great need for it:
examples: I'm not interested in government handouts - all I want is a job.

meanings.definition: something such as food, clothing, or money that is given free to someone who needs it:
examples: government handouts

meanings.definition: a document given to each person who is present, usually to give information about a particular subject:
examples: Her handout included a list of the books she referred to.

meanings.definition: something such as food, clothing, or money that is given free to someone who is in need of it:
examples: She ended up living on handouts and food vouchers.
federal/government/state handouts

meanings.definition: money that is paid to someone without their asking for it:
examples: The electricity company offered shareholders a £238m handout.
Shareholders are to receive a 25p a share cash handout after the company banked £219m from the sale last year.

meanings.definition: money that is given by a government to people, organizations, or industries to encourage a particular activity:
examples: More than 50 American billionaires have received government farm handouts in recent years from a program created to help struggling small farmers survive.

meanings.definition: a document containing information that is given to people at a meeting or other event:
examples: Keep the information in your media handout factual and to the point.

meanings.definition: the giving of control of or responsibility for something to someone else:
examples: The United Nations is to supervise the handover of the prisoners of war.

meanings.definition: the official act of giving something to someone after planning to do this:
examples: After the election, there was a peaceful handover of power to the new government.

meanings.definition: the act of giving responsibility for something to another person, or the period during which this happens:
examples: Company executives expect the handover to be relatively swift, with Norris taking over the chairman's role within weeks.
The handover of power is not going to happen before a general election.
an orderly/smooth handover
Now, after a handover period, he is leaving the board completely.

meanings.definition: Someone who is handpicked has been carefully chosen for a special job or purpose:
examples: a handpicked audience

meanings.definition: carefully chosen for a special job or purpose:
examples: He was the mayor’s hand-picked choice to lead the investigation.

meanings.definition: a mark left by someone's hand:
examples: There were dirty handprints all over the wall.

meanings.definition: a quality that something has that shows who has made, created, or influenced it:
examples: His name isn't anywhere on the film, but his handprints are everywhere.

meanings.definition: a long, narrow bar of wood or metal that people can hold on to for support, especially when going up or down stairs
definitely:
examples: If we had a race, he’d win hands down.

meanings.definition: a hands-free piece of equipment, especially a phone, can be used without needing to hold it in your hand:
examples: a hands-free car phone
a hands-free tap

meanings.definition: a piece of equipment, especially a phone, that you can use without needing to hold it in your hand
used to describe a piece of equipment, especially a phone, that you can use without needing to hold it:
examples: a hands-free cell phone/device/mobile

meanings.definition: Someone who has a hands-off way of organizing or dealing with something allows other people to make decisions about how things should be done and avoids becoming directly involved:
examples: Paul has a hands-off style of management.

meanings.definition: dealing with situations and people in a way that allows others to make decisions:
examples: a hands-off attitude/policy/style
The family is said to take a hands-off approach to the day-to-day running of the business they own.

meanings.definition: Someone with a hands-on way of doing things becomes closely involved in managing and organizing things and in making decisions:
examples: She's very much a hands-on manager.

meanings.definition: Someone who has hands-on experience of something has done or used it rather than just read or learned about it:
examples: Many employers consider hands-on experience to be as useful as academic qualifications.

meanings.definition: actively involved with other people in making decisions and doing work:
examples: She’s a hands-on manager.

meanings.definition: obtained by doing something, not by reading about it or by watching it done:
examples: hands-on experience/training/education

meanings.definition: directly involved in making decisions about the way in which things should be done:
examples: As a manager, she was always very hands-on.
a hands-on approach

meanings.definition: relating to or providing experience of something:
examples: On the course, the youth learn various job skills in a hands-on learning environment.
The technical college offers hands-on training for students who want to learn the building trades.

meanings.definition: knowledge or skill that someone gets from doing something rather than just reading about it or seeing it being done:
examples: They will participate in workshops and get hands-on experience leading classes.
He always said he learned more about newspapers from hands-on experience than he did in the classroom.

meanings.definition: a saw (= a tool that has a long or round blade with sharp points, for cutting hard materials such as wood) that is operated by hand rather than using electricity or a motor:
examples: My first bookshelf was made with a handsaw.
Police said the vandal must have used a handsaw instead of a chainsaw because people living nearby heard nothing.

meanings.definition: the outer part of a mobile phone that does not include the battery or the sim card
the part of a phone in two parts that you hold in front of your mouth and against your ear
a mobile phone:
examples: You may be tempted by the offer of a 40% discount off the price of a new pay-as-you-talk handset.
Some providers won't cover you if your handset is stolen from your car or if you mislay it.
a handset maker/manufacturer

meanings.definition: the part of a phone that you hold to your ear
a greeting, or an act showing that you have made an agreement, in which two people who are facing each other take hold of and shake each other's right hand:
examples: He welcomed me with a wide smile and a warm handshake.

meanings.definition: a greeting or expression of agreement in which two people who are facing each other take hold of each other’s right hands and move them up and down
a greeting in which two people who are facing each other take hold of each other's right hand and move it up and down:
examples: His charm begins with a warm smile, his arm on your shoulder and a firm handshake.

meanings.definition: a business agreement made informally without signing an agreement:
examples: a handshake agreement/deal
On a handshake, I've promised the first car to one of our established customers.

meanings.definition: golden handshake
a signal sent from one computer to another to show that they are ready to send and receive information:
examples: Hackers false requests for an electronic handshake with our machines are so numerous that the legitimate requests can't get through.

meanings.definition: the process by which computers send signals to each other to show that they are ready to send and receive information:
examples: electronic handshaking

meanings.definition: A handsome man is physically attractive in a traditional, male way:
examples: Her dream is to be whisked off her feet by a tall, dark, handsome stranger.

meanings.definition: A handsome woman is attractive in a strong way:
examples: a handsome woman in her fifties

meanings.definition: large in amount:
examples: They made a handsome profit on their house.

meanings.definition: (esp. of a man) physically attractive:
examples: He was handsome, brilliant, witty, and generally the center of attention wherever he was.

meanings.definition: (esp. of money) large in amount:
examples: a handsome salary

meanings.definition: very well or to a great degree:
examples: She said if his results were good, she would reward him handsomely.
Their strategy paid off handsomely.

meanings.definition: in a way that is physically attractive in a traditionally male way:
examples: At six feet, Bill was handsomely athletic.
He was a man of about sixty, handsomely dressed.

meanings.definition: a type of somersault (= movement in which you turn over completely) that involves moving forwards or backwards from a standing position to land on your hands and then back to a standing position:
examples: He slipped while doing back handsprings.
The children were doing cartwheels, handsprings, and forward rolls.

meanings.definition: an action in which you balance vertically on your hands with your legs pointing straight up in the air
an action in which you put your hands on the ground and push your legs up so that they point straight up
often touching people with your hands, especially when they do not want you to:
examples: He started to get a bit handsy with my wife.
The actor admitted that his co-star had been handsy with him.

meanings.definition: to wash something such as clothes or kitchen equipment yourself rather than putting them into a machine:
examples: Always try to hand-wash wooden utensils.
You've got to hand wash it in cold water because it's silk.
Even if you handwash, the colours eventually fade.

meanings.definition: a liquid substance used for cleaning your hands:
examples: To kill bacteria and viruses, use warm water and soap or an antibacterial handwash.

meanings.definition: the activity of washing something such as a piece of clothing yourself rather than putting it into a machine:
examples: A few items always need a handwash when you're on holiday.
The detergent can be used for both machine and hand washes.

meanings.definition: an act of washing your hands:
examples: At 30 seconds per hand wash, busy hospital workers could spend 10 minutes per hour washing their hands.

meanings.definition: to behave or talk as if a problem, question, etc. is not important or worth serious attention, for example by ignoring it, discussing it in a very general way, or discussing something else instead:
examples: I feel like the questions got handwaved off by the speaker.
His talk handwaved over some important details.
We handwave this inconsistency by assuming it was a revision error.

meanings.definition: an act of behaving or talking as if a problem, question, etc. is not important or worth serious attention, for example by ignoring it, discussing it in a very general way, or discussing something else instead:
examples: Paraphrasing someone's arguments in a sarcastic tone is a classic handwave.

meanings.definition: writing with a pen or pencil:
examples: We need to ensure that handwriting is properly taught in our primary schools.

meanings.definition: the particular way in which someone forms letters with a pen or pencil:
examples: His handwriting is illegible.

meanings.definition: a person’s style of writing done with a pen or pencil:
examples: His handwriting is so sloppy it’s hard to read.

meanings.definition: the examination of someone's writing as a way of learning about the type of person they are:
examples: Hopper says employers who use handwriting analysis prior to filling a vacancy can save themselves costly hiring mistakes.

meanings.definition: written using your hand rather than printed by a machine
written by someone using a pen or pencil:
examples: a handwritten thank-you note

meanings.definition: useful or convenient:
examples: a handy container/tool
First-time visitors to France will find this guide particularly handy.
It's a nice house and it's handy for (= near) the train station.
Don't throw those bottles away - they'll come in handy (= be useful) for the picnic next Sunday.

meanings.definition: able to use something skilfully:
examples: Jonathan's good at putting up wallpaper, but he's not so handy with a paintbrush.
Susannah's very handy (= good at doing things that need skilled use of the hands) about the house.

meanings.definition: useful or convenient:
examples: We found it handy to have a cellular phone.
When I’m cooking something new, I like to keep the cookbook handy (= in a convenient place).

meanings.definition: skillful with the hands or with using tools, esp. in making or repairing things:
examples: Eduardo is handy with power tools.

meanings.definition: useful or convenient:
examples: Credit cards are a handy way of paying for things as long as the rates are not too high.
The personal finance software includes handy features such as automatic bill payment reminders.
What skills do you have that might come in handy?

meanings.definition: a man who is skilled at repairing and making things inside or outside the house and who does this in his own home or as a job
a man who works at many small jobs in and around a building, esp. repairing things
a woman who is skilled at repairing and making things inside or outside the house and who does this in her own home or as a job
to fasten or support something at the top leaving the other parts free to move, or to be held in this way:
examples: A heavy gold necklace hung around her neck.
Party decorations hung (down) from the ceiling.
The curtains hung in thick folds.
Hang your coat and hat (up) on the rack over there.
Many of his finest pictures hang/are hung (= are attached to the wall so that they can be seen) in the National Gallery.

meanings.definition: If you hang wallpaper, you fix it to the wall.
to hang up a bird or animal after killing it in order to make the meat relax and have a stronger taste, or to be hung up in this way:
examples: Hanging meat is really important to the quality of the meat, and is the first stage of good butchery.
Let the pheasant hang for a few days for the flavour to improve before you cook it.

meanings.definition: to kill someone, especially as punishment for a serious crime, by dropping them with a rope tied around their neck, or to die in this way:
examples: He was found guilty and hanged later that year.
With so little evidence to prove her guilt, few people thought she should hang.
The woman tried to hang herself with a sheet.

meanings.definition: to stay in the air:
examples: The falcon seemed to hang in the air for a moment before diving onto its prey.
Smoke from the houses hung above the village.
The sound of the bells hung in the midnight air.

meanings.definition: to curve down:
examples: The branches hung heavy with snow.
He knew he'd done something wrong and hung his head in shame.

meanings.definition: to spend time relaxing with a person or in a place:
examples: Ashley spent most of the evening hanging with her friend.
Sometimes we just hang in the park.

meanings.definition: (of a computer program or system) to stop working or appearing on a screen:
examples: In the middle of a download, it just hangs.
The update prevents the system from hanging when it receives a corrupt data fragment.

meanings.definition: If a pitcher in baseball hangs the ball, or if the ball hangs, it is thrown badly so that it does not spin very much and it is easy for the batter to hit it hard:
examples: Weaver hung a curveball, which Garcia hit for a home run.
His first pitch was a hanging slider.

meanings.definition: to attach or support something at the top, leaving the other part parts free, or to be held in this way:
examples: There was no wind, and the flag hung straight down.
I plan to hang this picture in the hall.

meanings.definition: to kill someone by fixing a rope around the neck and tying it to something above the person and then causing the body to drop down suddenly:
examples: He was sentenced to die and was hanged the next morning.

meanings.definition: to stay in the air:
examples: Smoke from the campfires hung in the air.

meanings.definition: to turn to the left or right:
examples: Hang a left/right at the next corner.

meanings.definition: to start running a business:
examples: Dr James first hung his shingle in Oakland in the mid-1970s.
Some people hang their own shingle when they are tired of the corporate 9 to 5.
So can anyone just hang out a shingle and start practising?
At the time, pretty much anyone could hang out a shingle and announce that they were a minister.
These people just hang out a shingle and claim to be consultants.

meanings.definition: to move or do things slowly:
examples: Go and pack but don't hang around - we have to go in an hour.

meanings.definition: to wait or spend time somewhere, usually for no particular reason:
examples: I spent most of my youth hanging around the bars of Dublin.
I thought I'd hang around for a while and see if she comes.

meanings.definition: to wait at a place, or to stay near a place or person, often for no particular reason:
examples: We were just hanging around the mall.
She hangs around with some tough kids.

meanings.definition: to spend time with someone:
examples: I got into drugs because I was hanging around with the wrong people.

meanings.definition: to be slow to do something, often because of fear or having no confidence:
examples: There's no need to hang back - you can sing as well as anyone.

meanings.definition: to wait before doing something, esp. when others have already begun:
examples: Most of them went up to their hotel rooms, but I hung back.

meanings.definition: If a serious situation hangs by a thread, it means that even a slight change can decide what will happen and that a bad result such as death, failure, etc. is likely:
examples: The mayor's political future has been hanging by a thread since the fraud scandal.

meanings.definition: said as a way of telling someone to not give up, despite difficulties:
examples: Work can get tough in the middle of a term but hang in there and it'll be OK.

meanings.definition: do not give up:
examples: Hang in there – exams are almost over.

meanings.definition: to wait for a short time:
examples: Sally's on the other phone - would you like to hang on?
Do you need the toilet right now or can you hang on for a while?
Hang on a minute - I'll be with you in a moment!

meanings.definition: to hold or continue holding onto something:
examples: Hang on tight - it's going to be a very bumpy ride.

meanings.definition: to blame someone for something, especially something they did not do:
examples: I wasn't anywhere near the house when the window was broken, so you can't hang that on me!

meanings.definition: to hold or continue holding onto something:
examples: He was driving so fast I had to hang on tight whenever he turned.

meanings.definition: to wait:
examples: Hang on – I’ll be with you in a minute!

meanings.definition: to listen very carefully to someone’s speech:
examples: She hung on every word he said.

meanings.definition: to give careful attention to something, especially something that someone says:
examples: He hangs on her every word as if she were some sort of goddess.

meanings.definition: to depend on something:
examples: The safety of air travel hangs partly on the thoroughness of baggage checking.

meanings.definition: to keep something:
examples: You should hang onto that painting - it might be valuable.

meanings.definition: to keep something, often when you must make an effort to do this:
examples: Our team was just trying to hang onto the lead.

meanings.definition: to spend a lot of time in a place or with someone:
examples: You still hang out at the pool hall?
I've been hanging out backstage with the band.

meanings.definition: to spend a lot of time in a place or with someone:
examples: Who is he hanging out with these days?

meanings.definition: If a threat or doubt hangs over a place or a situation, it exists:
examples: Uncertainty again hangs over the project.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         hang around (somewhere)

→ 
        
         hang around with someone
to allow someone to be punished, criticized, or made to suffer in a way that is unfair, without trying to help them:
examples: They felt they had been hung out to dry by their employers.
He said, "We will not let the media hang this man out to dry."

meanings.definition: the cost is not important:
examples: Just buy it and hang the expense!

meanings.definition: in American football, the amount of time the ball is in the air when it is kicked:
examples: He impressed during the preseason, getting great hang time and distance.

meanings.definition: the amount of time a sports person is in the air, for example, when a basketball player jumps, or the amount of time an object is in the air, such as a kite or hang-glider:
examples: He combined extended hang time with grace and power.
When you're kitesurfing, hangtime is when the kite is used to perform massive jumps and remains suspended in the air for as long as possible.

meanings.definition: If people hang together, they help each other and work together to achieve something:
examples: If the opposition party can hang together over the next six months, they might just stand a chance of being elected.

meanings.definition: If the parts of something hang together, they are well organized or they seem to be true or correct:
examples: Somehow her story doesn't quite hang together.

meanings.definition: to not change your actions or opinions although other people try to make you do this:
examples: The president is hanging tough on the hostage crisis.

meanings.definition: to end a phone conversation:
examples: He started shouting so I hung up (on him).
Let me speak to Melanie before you hang up.

meanings.definition: to stop using and needing something because you have given up the sport or activity it is used for:
examples: So when did you hang up your boxing gloves/golf clubs/ballet shoes?

meanings.definition: a permanent and unreasonable feeling of worry about a particular thing, especially about a particular feature of yourself:
examples: She claims the marriage failed due to his emotional hang-ups.
Everyone has their own hangups.
He went bald very young and has a terrible hang-up about it.

meanings.definition: a difficulty that causes a delay:
examples: It is best to fix hangups as soon as they occur.
The machines had only minor hang-ups, and those were resolved quickly.

meanings.definition: to end a telephone conversation by ending the connection:
examples: Don’t hang up – there’s something else I want to say.
She hung up on me (= suddenly ended the connection between us) in the middle of a sentence.

meanings.definition: to place something, esp. clothing, on a hook or hanger:
examples: Hang your coat up and come on in.

meanings.definition: a problem that causes a delay:
examples: The doctor never got back to me with the test results – I guess there was some hang-up over the weekend.

meanings.definition: A hang-up is also a feeling of anxiety:
examples: Everyone has their hang-up.

meanings.definition: to be ashamed or unhappy:
examples: We played a great game – we have no reason to hang our heads.

meanings.definition: a very small aircraft without an engine, consisting of a frame covered in cloth, from which the pilot hangs
an aircraft consisting of a light frame over which cloth or similar material is stretched, so that a person can jump off from a high place and ride the air currents
the activity of flying through the air by hanging from a very small aircraft without an engine, consisting of a frame covered in cloth:
examples: She's taken up hang-gliding.
It was with Laura that he had first tried hang-gliding.

meanings.definition: an amount of money you still owe on a loan at the end of the period in which you agreed to pay it back
to delay making a decision:
examples: Ideally we would settle the matter now, but I think we should hang fire until the general situation becomes clearer.

meanings.definition: to hold on very tightly to something, despite great difficulty:
examples: Darren always drives and I sit behind him, hanging on like grim death.

meanings.definition: to be calm and relaxed
a large building in which aircraft are kept
a large building in an airport in which aircraft are kept
(of an expression on a face) unhappy or ashamed, especially because of feeling guilty:
examples: a hangdog look/expression

meanings.definition: a curved piece of wire, wood, or plastic on which clothes are hung while they are being stored
a frame of wire, wood, or plastic on which clothes are hung to keep them neat when you are not wearing them
a steak (= a thick, flat piece of meat) from the front of a cow :
examples: Try the hanger steak with fried onions and balsamic glaze.
Not only were the hanger steaks delicious, the servings were huge and the price very reasonable.

meanings.definition: a person who tries to be friendly and spend time with rich and important people, especially to get an advantage:
examples: Wherever there is royalty, there are always hangers-on.

meanings.definition: a person who tries to be friendly and spend time with rich or important people to get some advantage:
examples: Wherever there are rock stars, there are always hangers-on.

meanings.definition:
plural of 
        
         hanger-on   disapproving
the act of killing someone, especially as a punishment for a serious crime, by dropping that person with a rope tied around their neck:
examples: Hanging was abolished in the UK in 1969.
The hangings drew criticism from abroad.

meanings.definition: a large piece of cloth, often with a picture on it, that is hung on a wall for decoration:
examples: The house had marble columns and silk hangings.
The walls and floors were decorated with Indian rugs and hangings.

meanings.definition: the practice of killing someone by dropping them down suddenly with a rope tied around the neck:
examples: He was present at the hangings of dozens of outlaws in the 1860s.

meanings.definition: an open container with plants and flowers in it, hung around eye level in public areas for decoration
a small piece that is still partly attached to a piece of paper or card after someone has tried to make a hole in it, for example as a way of showing who they are voting for in an election:
examples: An estimated 46,000 city and county voters clearly intended to vote but left only dimples or hanging chads.
Do any states still use the old paper punch card ballots with their hanging chads?

meanings.definition: a folded piece of thin cardboard that hangs in a drawer, and in which documents can be stored in an organized way:
examples: In the so-called "paperless office," walls of hanging files are being stored in darkened rooms where they are re-classed as archives.

meanings.definition: the use of a space at the start of every line of a paragraph except the first line:
examples: Instead of using tabs and hanging indents, left-justify the entire document.

meanings.definition: a valley that ends suddenly with a steep cliff or waterfall where it meets the side of a larger, deeper valley
a person whose job is to operate the device that kills criminals by hanging them from a rope by their necks

a word game in which one player has to guess a word that the other player has thought of, by guessing the letters in it. Every time they guess a wrong letter, part of a picture of a person being hanged is drawn, and if the picture is completed the person guessing has lost.
a small piece of torn skin at the edge of a fingernail:
examples: I had a hangnail that was really hurting me.

meanings.definition: a place where someone spends a lot of time, or where someone lives:

meanings.definition: a feeling of illness you get the day after drinking too much alcohol
becoming angry because you are feeling hungry:
examples: People often get hangry when their blood sugar level is low.

meanings.definition: a dish made of eggs fried with oysters (= a large, flat sea creature that lives in a shell) and bacon (= preserved meat from the back or sides of a pig):
examples: Try the local Hangtown Fry, an omelette-like mix-up of bacon, eggs, and breaded oysters.

meanings.definition: a thick piece, or a bunch (= a number of long pieces held together) of hair, thread, rope, etc.:

meanings.definition: to have a strong desire for something:

meanings.definition: a strong wish:

meanings.definition: a handkerchief (= square piece of cloth or paper used for cleaning the nose and drying the eyes)
a small, often decorative handkerchief (= square piece of cloth)
unacceptable or dishonest behaviour, especially involving sexual activity or money:

meanings.definition: dishonest or immoral behavior:

meanings.definition: the capital city of Vietnam, in the northern part of the country:

meanings.definition: the official record of what is said and done in the British, Australian, New Zealand, Canadian, and South African parliaments
a two-wheeled vehicle pulled by a horse, used like a taxi in the past:

meanings.definition: a Jewish religious holiday lasting for eight days in December

someone who has one Hawaiian or East Asian parent and one white parent:

meanings.definition: not having an obvious order or plan:

meanings.definition: lacking order or purpose; not planned:

meanings.definition: in a way that does not have an obvious order or plan:

meanings.definition: a sport, created in Korea as a type of self-defence, that involves kicks, punches, throws, and other movements:

meanings.definition: unlucky and usually unhappy:

meanings.definition: unlucky:

meanings.definition: in an unlucky way, or in a way that has bad or unhappy results:

meanings.definition: having a single set of chromosomes (= structures containing chemical patterns that control what a plant or animal is like) that comes from one parent only:

meanings.definition: (of a situation or an event) to have existence or come into existence:
examples: No one knows exactly what happened but several people have been hurt.
Anything could happen in the next half hour.

I don't want to think about what might have happened if he'd been driving any faster.

meanings.definition: to do or be by chance:
examples: They happened to look (= looked by chance) in the right place almost immediately.
Fortunately it happened (that) there was no one in the house at the time of the explosion.
It just so happens that I have her phone number right here.
She happens to like cleaning (= she likes cleaning, although that is surprising).
I happen to think he's right (= I do think so, although you do not).

meanings.definition: perhaps:
examples: Happen it'll rain later on.

meanings.definition: (of a situation or event) to come into existence; occur:
examples: If you want to know what is happening in the world, you have to read the newspapers.

meanings.definition: If a situation or event happens to someone or something, it has an effect on that person or thing:

meanings.definition: to do or be by chance:
examples: I happened to come across this book I think you would like.

meanings.definition: to exist or begin to exist because of an action, situation, or event:
examples: The one course of events no one anticipated was the one that happened: a long period of stagnation that threatened the assumptions of the European welfare state.

meanings.definition: to be done or exist by chance:
examples: What happens in one country or region may not happen in another.

meanings.definition: to go to a place by chance or without planning to:
examples: I'd have drowned if he hadn't happened along and pulled me out of the river.

meanings.definition: to find or meet something or someone by chance:
examples: Eventually they happened on a road leading across the desert.

meanings.definition: to meet or find someone or something when you were not looking for that person or thing:
examples: I happened on the perfect dress for the party.

meanings.definition: If something happens to someone or something, it has an effect on him, her, or it:
examples: I don't know what I'd do if anything happened to him (= if he was hurt, became ill, or died).

What's happened to my pen? (= Where is it?) I put it down there a few moments ago.

meanings.definition: in a happy way:

meanings.definition: (used in greetings for special occasions) full of enjoyment and pleasure:

meanings.definition: lucky:

meanings.definition: someone who is happy with their situation:

meanings.definition: happy or happily for the rest of your life, especially in a romantic relationship: a situation in which someone is happy and satisfied for the rest of their life, especially in a romantic relationship:

meanings.definition: a period of time, usually in the early evening, when drinks are sold cheaply in a bar or a pub

to annoy someone, especially by repeatedly asking them something:
examples: I'll do it in my own time - just stop hassling me!
The children keep hassling me to take them to Disneyland.

meanings.definition: in the past, the second person singular form of the present tense of "have":
examples: thou hast (= you have)

meanings.definition: (too much) speed:
examples: Unfortunately the report was prepared in haste and contained several inaccuracies.
In her haste to get up from the table, she knocked over a cup.
His father had just died and he didn't want to marry with indecent haste.

meanings.definition: great speed:
examples: In spite of all their haste, they didn’t have time to finish.
Officials acted in haste (= too quickly), without understanding the situation.

meanings.definition: to make something happen sooner or more quickly:
examples: There is little doubt that poor medical treatment hastened her death.
These recent poor results have hastened the manager's departure.

meanings.definition: If you hasten to do something, you quickly do it:
examples: The president hastened to reassure his people that he was in perfect health.

meanings.definition: If you hasten somewhere, you go there quickly:
examples: Reporters hastened from the press conference to call their editors.
From her office on the first floor, she hastened upstairs to speak to her boss.

meanings.definition: to hurry, or to make something go or happen faster:
examples: They didn’t get what they were after – thanks to you, I hasten to add.
To hasten softening, place the cream cheese in the oven for a few minutes.

hasten-to-add-say-point-out-etc.name: hasten to add, say, point out, etc.

meanings.definition: to emphasize that you want to make something clear:
examples: This was my own money that I was using, I hasten to add.
"People around here dress so badly - except you, Justin," she hastened to add.
It was an unfortunate decision and I hasten to say it had nothing to do with me.
The culprits are not, I should hasten to point out, necessarily all men.
"This is temporary," she hastened to remind him.
He hastens to explain that the story is not autobiographical.

meanings.definition: to dislike someone or something very much:
examples: Kelly hates her teacher.

I hate it when you do that.
I have always hated speaking in public.
I hate him telling me what to do all the time.
I hate (= do not want) to interrupt, but it's time we left.
I'd hate (= would not like) you to think I didn't appreciate what you'd done.

meanings.definition: an extremely strong dislike:
examples: She gave him a look of pure hate.

meanings.definition: to strongly dislike someone or something:
examples: Kelly hates her teacher.
I have always hated speaking in public.
I hate to say it, but I don’t think Leo is the right man for the job.

meanings.definition: a crime or crimes, usually involving violence, committed against someone because of their race or religion, because they are gay, etc. :
examples: New figures show that hate crime rose 14% over the last 12 months.
A transgender woman's death is now being investigated as a hate crime by the police department.

meanings.definition: unpleasant or cruel letters from someone who dislikes you

examples: These kids get hated on for no good reason at all.

meanings.definition: to dislike someone very much
to hate someone very much:
examples: She hates her ex-boyfriend's guts.

meanings.definition: public speech that expresses hate or encourages violence towards a person or group based on something such as race, religion, sex, or sexual orientation (= the fact of being gay, etc.):
examples: Citing a law prohibiting hate speech against a minority, a district court sentenced him to a month in prison.

meanings.definition: to read a book, article, blog, etc. that you dislike or think is very bad, because you enjoy laughing at it or criticizing it:

meanings.definition: a book, article, blog, etc. that you dislike or think is very bad, but read because you enjoy laughing at it or criticizing it:

meanings.definition: to watch a TV programme, film, etc. that you dislike or think is very bad, because you enjoy laughing at it or criticizing it:

It's absolutely terrible, but I've hatewatched every episode.

meanings.definition: a TV programme, film, etc. that you dislike or think is very bad, but watch because you enjoy laughing at it or criticizing it:
examples: I thought this was supposed to be a hate-watch but I ended up genuinely loving it.

meanings.definition: disliked very strongly and by many people:

meanings.definition: very unpleasant:
examples: I never wear grey because it reminds me of my hateful school uniform.

meanings.definition: filled with or causing strong dislike:

meanings.definition: a person who says or writes unpleasant things about someone or criticizes their achievements, especially on the internet:

meanings.definition: someone who dislikes the stated thing:

examples: They hauled the boat out of the water.

meanings.definition: to take something or someone somewhere, especially by force:
examples: FBI agents hauled away boxes of records.

meanings.definition: to transport something, usually by road:

meanings.definition: a journey, often a difficult one:

meanings.definition: to pull something heavy or transport something over long distances:

examples: In 2006, shippers on the Great Lakes hauled 110 million tons of cargo.

meanings.definition: to make someone go to a person in authority to answer questions about something they have done:

meanings.definition: a large amount of something that is illegal or has been stolen:

meanings.definition: a distance travelled carrying goods:

meanings.definition: to move very quickly to a different place:
examples: When the shooting started we hauled ass out of there.

meanings.definition: to force someone to go somewhere or see someone in order to be punished or to answer questions about their behaviour:
examples: He was hauled up in court/in front of a judge.

meanings.definition: to take someone or something somewhere:
examples: Most of the buildings are simply flattened and hauled away to local dumps.

meanings.definition: to eat or drink something:

meanings.definition: to suffer something that someone does to you:

meanings.definition: to experience something:

meanings.definition: to give birth to a baby:

meanings.definition: to have sex with someone:

meanings.definition: used with the past participle of other verbs to form perfect tenses:

meanings.definition: to do an action:
examples: He didn’t have a birthday party this year.

meanings.definition: Have can also mean eat or drink:

meanings.definition: To have a baby is to give birth:
examples: Glennis had a girl.

meanings.definition: to receive or accept something, or to allow something to happen:
examples: I’ll have some more coffee.

I won’t have those kids running through my flower bed.

meanings.definition: to cause something to happen, or to cause someone to do something:

meanings.definition: to experience something:
examples: We had a wonderful vacation.

meanings.definition: to own or possess something:
examples: We have a dog.

I’ve got a big nose.
Have you got any money on you (= Are you carrying money with you)?

meanings.definition: Have can also mean to be related to, or to know:
examples: Carol has six sisters.

meanings.definition: If a store has something, it is available to be bought:

meanings.definition: to contain or include something:
examples: The Chicago area has a population of about eight million.

meanings.definition: to be involved with something or have influence on something:

meanings.definition: to be very much in love
to be certain to be successful and have a good life, often without much effort:
examples: With his father at the head of the firm, he's got it made.

meanings.definition: infml to be successful or rich: If you have it made, you are able to relax and do not have to worry about work or other problems:
examples: Everyone thinks if you’re in a hit movie, you’ve got it made.
You’re taking all the easy classes this semester – you’ve got it made!

meanings.definition: to be responsible for something bad that has happened:

meanings.definition: to realize, understand, or know something about a situation, plan, etc.:

meanings.definition: to have someone in your power

examples: Don't worry. I've got your back.

meanings.definition: to have solved a problem
If you have clothes or shoes on, you are wearing them:
examples: I loved that dress you had on last night.

meanings.definition: If you have something on, you have planned to do it:

meanings.definition: to be wearing particular clothes or items of clothing:

meanings.definition: to know secret or damaging information about someone:

meanings.definition: (of machines, electric devices, and equipment) to be operating or in use:

meanings.definition: to be very sexually attracted to someone:

meanings.definition: to need to or be forced:

meanings.definition: used to say that something must be true:

have-got-to-hand-it-to.name: have (got) to hand it to someone

meanings.definition: If you say you have (got) to hand it to someone you mean that they have been very successful or skilful:
examples: I mean you've got to hand it to her, she's brought up those three children all on her own.

meanings.definition: to recognize that someone deserves respect for what the person did:

meanings.definition: to be very busy or involved with something:
