have-got-heart-set-on.name: have (got) your heart set on something

meanings.definition: to want something very much, so that you would be very disappointed if you do not get it:
examples: She’s got her heart set on ballet lessons.

meanings.definition: infml to not be willing or able to continue doing something: If something has had it, it is not working any longer:
examples: We’ve been to three museums today and I’ve just about had it.
This old vacuum cleaner has had it.

have-more-than-share-of.name: have (more than) your share of something

meanings.definition: to have had a lot or too much of something:
examples: We’ve had our share of problems with the new computer system.

meanings.definition: to have sex or a sexual relationship with someone:
examples: The couple had been having sexual relations for a year.

meanings.definition: to be responsible for someone's death:
examples: The leaders of this war have the blood of many thousands of people on their hands.

meanings.definition: to have a natural ability to do something well:
examples: Kim has a head for numbers.

meanings.definition: to be good at finding things of the stated type:
examples: She has a good nose for a bargain.
As a reporter, he had a nose for a good story.

meanings.definition: to enjoy yourself very much:
examples: "So how was the party last night?" "Oh, it was great - we had a ball!"

meanings.definition: to try to do something you have not done before:
examples: I've never been skiing before, but I'm prepared to have a bash (at it).
I had a bash at learning Mandarin but I didn't get very far.
During this meeting, we're going to have a bash at coming up with some new product ideas.
He wanted me to play tennis and I agreed to have a bash.
I didn't want to be a pianist but I thought I might have a bash at composing.

meanings.definition: to have an influence on something or a relationship to something:
examples: What you decide now could have a considerable bearing on your future.
It was clear that this testimony could have a bearing on the case we were investigating.
The success of each team has a bearing on its finances.
Studies show that height doesn't appear to have a bearing on a child's popularity.
The fall in annual profit may have had a bearing on her resignation.

have-a-bee-in-bonnet.name: have a bee in your bonnet

meanings.definition: to keep talking about something again and again because you think it is very important:
examples: She never stops talking about healthy eating - she's got a real bee in her bonnet about it.

meanings.definition: a phrase used to mean to forget something or do something silly, which is sometimes considered offensive because it is used to suggest that women with blonde hair are not intelligent

have-a-bone-to-pick-with.name: have a bone to pick with someone

meanings.definition: to want to talk to someone about something annoying they have done:
examples: I've got a bone to pick with you - you've been using my shaver again.

meanings.definition: to have a sudden clever idea:
examples: I couldn't see how I could get home from the station - then I had a brainstorm.
The toy's inventor was watching his children play one day when he had a brainstorm.

meanings.definition: to be suddenly unable to think clearly:
examples: I must have had a brainstorm - I went shopping and forgot to take any money.
He's usually an excellent manager, but he seems to have had a brainstorm when he picked this squad.

meanings.definition: to have a sudden clever idea:
examples: I couldn't see how I could get home from the station - then I had a brainwave.
The toy's inventor was watching his children play one day when he had a brainwave.

meanings.definition: to have a difficult time:
examples: She's had a bumpy ride at work over the last few months.

have-a-bun-in-the-oven.name: have a bun in the oven

meanings.definition: to be pregnant
to look at something:
examples: Let's have a butcher's at your present, then.

meanings.definition: to look at something:
examples: Let's have a butcher's at your present, then.
I've got a new car. Come round and have a butcher's if you like.

have-a-card-up-sleeve.name: have a card up your sleeve

meanings.definition: to have an advantage that other people do not know about:
examples: England have definitely been the weaker side, but I think they've still got one or two cards up their sleeve.

meanings.definition: used to tell someone to be more careful
to have a conversation, usually one that is friendly and informal:
examples: Why don't you give me a call and we'll have a chat?
I had a chat with my boss today about a possible salary increase.

have-a-chip-on-shoulder.name: have a chip on your shoulder

meanings.definition: to seem angry all the time because you think you have been treated unfairly or feel you are not as good as other people:
examples: He's got a chip on his shoulder about not having been to university.

meanings.definition: to know enough about something to able to use it effectively:
examples: He has a basic command of English.
She demonstrates an impressive command of the facts of the case.

have-a-corner-on-a-market.name: have a corner on a market

meanings.definition: If a company has a corner on a particular market, it is more successful than any other company at selling a particular type of product.
to be very worried, upset, or angry about something:
examples: My mother had a cow when I said I was going to buy a motorbike.

meanings.definition: to have or get an opportunity to attempt to do something:
examples: It's time to let someone else have a crack.
We had a crack at surfing during a break in Barbados.
The airport is taking a crack at making security lines a little more bearable.

meanings.definition: to be involved in an accident whilst driving a vehicle, usually a serious accident in which the vehicle is damaged or someone is hurt:
examples: I'm a good driver and have never had a crash.
You need car insurance in case you have a crash.

meanings.definition: to have a strong but temporary feeling of liking someone romantically:
examples: I often thought he had a bit of a crush on you.
I had this huge crush on him for about two years.

meanings.definition: to disagree:
examples: They had a difference of opinion about their child's education.
We had a difference of opinion over the direction of the company.
The president has admitted that they have a difference of opinion on this issue.
I had a difference of opinion with my boss.
It seems Tom and I have a difference of opinion about how much we're going to spend on the kitchen.
We had a difference of opinion but it's okay now.

meanings.definition: to have a noisy argument or fight:
examples: They were a having a right ding-dong the other day!
We disagreed sometimes, but we never really had any ding-dongs.

have-a-dog-in-the-fight.name: have a dog in the fight

meanings.definition: to be involved in or affected by a situation personally:
examples: Donations of money should not be accepted from people who have a dog in the fight.
Lawyers could hold a grudge against a particular judge, or vice versa, but jurors do not have a dog in the fight.
This is between myself and my insurance company and I don't see that the government has any dog in the fight.
We don't have a dog in this fight — we're just here to fix a problem.
We have no dog in this fight, but we want a fair outcome for everybody.

meanings.definition: to dislike someone, often unfairly:
examples: Why do you have a down on him? I think he seems really nice.
He's convinced that one of his teachers has a down on him.
She denied that she had a down on Max when I asked her.
He probably thinks I have a down on his mum, but I think she's lovely.
She's horrible to me. I think she's got a down on me.

have-a-face-like-the-back-end-of-a-bus.name: have a face like the back end of a bus

meanings.definition: to be very ugly
to look extremely angry:
examples: She suddenly came into the room with a face like thunder.

meanings.definition: to seem or sound like something you have heard or seen before:
examples: Her name had a familiar ring to it.
I didn't know who was speaking, but his voice had a familiar ring.

meanings.definition: to drink quite a large number of, or too many, alcoholic drinks:
examples: By the look of her, she'd had a few even before she arrived at the party.

have-irons-in-the-fire.name: have a few, several, etc. irons in the fire

meanings.definition: to be involved with many activities or jobs at the same time or to make certain that there are always several possibilities available:
examples: If that job application doesn't work out I've got a couple more irons in the fire.

meanings.definition: to take advantage of an opportunity to do something you enjoy:
examples: The newspapers had a field day when the wedding was announced (= they wrote a lot about it and printed many photographs of it).

meanings.definition: to gain advantage or success from a situation, esp. one that is bad for someone else:
examples: When the press found out about the stolen money, they had a field day.

have-a-finger-in-every-pie.name: have a finger in every pie

meanings.definition: to be involved in and have influence over many different activities, often in a way that people do not approve of

have-a-finger-in-the-pie.name: have a finger in the pie

meanings.definition: to be involved in something, often when your involvement is not wanted
to become very angry:
examples: My mother threw a fit when she saw the mess we made.

meanings.definition: to quickly look at the pages of a book, magazine, etc.:
examples: I've had a flick through their brochure and it looks quite interesting.
Have a flick through these books and see if anything catches your eye.
I had a quick flick through the magazine but didn't read any of the articles.
While I was waiting, I had a quick flick through a gardening magazine.
I had a cursory flick through the book but it wasn't really my thing.

meanings.definition: to have a short sexual relationship with someone:
examples: She's been having a fling with her boss.

have-a-foot-in-both-camps.name: have a foot in both camps

meanings.definition: to be connected to two groups with opposing interests

have-a-frog-in-throat.name: have a frog in your throat

meanings.definition: to have difficulty in speaking because your throat feels dry and you want to cough
to be especially skilled at a particular activity:
examples: She has a genius for raising money.
Emily has a genius for saying just the right thing to make you feel better about yourself.
He had a real genius for finding the right people to work together.
The man has a genius for stating the obvious.
She isn't exactly overburdened with talent but there's no denying she has a genius for self-promotion.

meanings.definition: to criticize someone:
examples: My Dad's always having a go at me about getting a proper job.
She's been having a go at me about the state of my bedroom.
She was having a go at TV chefs for using too much meat in their dishes.
You seem determined to have a go at her for no good reason.
They're always having a go at the kids for not doing enough homework.

have-a-good-head-on-shoulders.name: have a good head on your shoulders

meanings.definition: to have good judgment and be able to make good decisions:
examples: I think she has a very good head on her shoulders. She knows the facts and she doesn't let the pressure get to her.
We're looking for someone who is smart and has a good head on their shoulders.

meanings.definition: If you say that someone has had a good innings, you mean that they have had a long and successful life:
examples: He was 86 when he died so I suppose he'd had a good innings.

meanings.definition: used when saying goodbye to someone:
examples: "Maybe I'll see you next week." - "Yeah, have a good one." - "You too, bye."
"Thank you very much." - "You're welcome. Have a good one."
See you later, man. You have a good one.
OK then. Well, have a good one.
"Well, I enjoyed talking with you." — "Me too. You have a good one!"

have-a-good-run-for-money.name: have a good run for your money

meanings.definition: to get a lot of success or pleasure from something that was never going to last forever:
examples: I've achieved a lot in my life and I feel I've had a good run for my money.
I thought it was about time I settled down, knowing I'd had a good run for my money.
He has had a good run for his money but it's time for someone younger to take over.
It would have been nice to make it all the way to the final but we've had a good run.
The golfer was philosophical about losing his ranking, saying, "I've had a good run."

meanings.definition: to get a lot of success or pleasure from something that was never going to last forever:
examples: It would have been nice to make it all the way to the final but we've had a good run.
The golfer was philosophical about losing his ranking, saying, "I've had a good run."
I've achieved a lot in my life and I feel I've had a good run for my money.
I thought it was about time I settled down, knowing I'd had a good run for my money.
He has had a good run for his money but it's time for someone younger to take over.

meanings.definition: to behave in a way that is successful and admired during a war, or during a difficult time period that can be seen as similar to a war:
examples: Unlike so many of his shell-shocked generation, Spencer had a good war.
He had a good war, serving as a captain with the 9th Lancers, and was awarded the MC.
The president of the Farmers' Union had a good war, impressing ministers with his calm handling of the foot-and-mouth crisis.
It was agreed that the BBC had had a good pandemic.

have-a-good-healthy-pair-of-lungs.name: have a good/healthy pair of lungs

meanings.definition: You say that a baby has a good/healthy pair of lungs when it cries loudly.
to be in a position where you can see something very well:
examples: From our hotel room window, we had a grandstand view of the parade.

meanings.definition: to be very kind and generous:
examples: She has a heart of gold.

meanings.definition: to be unkind or cruel
used to ask someone to be kinder to you:
examples: Don't make me write it again! Have a heart!

meanings.definition: to show kindness and sympathy:
examples: Please let me go to the party – have a heart!

meanings.definition: to drive a car too fast:
examples: She has a heavy foot - does the trip in half the time it takes me!

meanings.definition: to hate something very much or be very frightened of something:
examples: It may be childish but I have a horror of worms.

have-a-horse-in-the-race.name: have a horse in the race

meanings.definition: to be personally involved in or affected by something:
examples: It's probably going to bring a lot of people out to the election because everyone will have a horse in the race.
My people have a horse in this race, too.
Being a private institution we're not tied to any state funding, so we don't have a horse in that race.

have-a-leg-up-on.name: have a leg up on someone

meanings.definition: to have an advantage over someone

have-a-lot-of-time-for.name: have a lot of time for someone

meanings.definition: to like someone and be interested in them:
examples: She's really nice - I have a lot of time for Helen.

have-a-lot-to-answer-for.name: have a lot to answer for

meanings.definition: to be the main cause of a problem or an unpleasant situation:
examples: People who sell drugs to kids have a lot to answer for.
In my opinion, the far-right has a lot to answer for.
When it comes to weird and wonderful art installations, Duchamp has a lot to answer for.
How on earth did that boy end up so messed up? His parents have a lot to answer for.
The press has a lot to answer for when it comes to the demonization of social workers.

have-a-lot-to-say-for.name: have a lot to say for yourself

meanings.definition: to talk too much and seem to have a high opinion of yourself

have-a-memory-like-an-elephant.name: have a memory like an elephant

meanings.definition: to be able to remember things easily and for a long period of time

have-a-mind-of-its-own.name: have a mind of its own

meanings.definition: A machine or other object can be said to have a mind of its own if it seems to be controlling the way it behaves or moves, independently of the person using it:
examples: This shopping trolley has a mind of its own.

meanings.definition: to think that something bad is likely to happen or to be true:
examples: I've got a nasty feeling that I forgot to tell Joe I couldn't come.
I had a nasty feeling that something worse was in store for all of us.
I had a nasty feeling that all this was about to change.
I have a nasty feeling that Isabel may not have heard the news.
I've got a nasty feeling that those are the wrong keys.

have-a-nice-good-etc-line-in.name: have a nice, good, etc. line in something

meanings.definition: to do something skilfully and successfully:
examples: He has a good line in anecdotes.

have-a-nodding-acquaintance-with.name: have a nodding acquaintance with someone/something

meanings.definition: to know someone slightly or have a slight knowledge of a subject:
examples: She has only a nodding acquaintance with the issues involved.

have-a-passing-slight-nodding-acquaintan.name: have a passing/slight/nodding acquaintance with something

meanings.definition: to have very little knowledge or experience of a subject:
examples: I'm afraid I have only a nodding acquaintance with his works.

meanings.definition: to find something or someone annoying or offensive:
examples: I have a real problem with people who use their mobile phones on the train.
She can smoke - I don't have a problem with that.

meanings.definition: to enjoy yourself very much: to have difficulty:
examples: We went on a tour of the city's bars and had a rare old time.
We had a rare old time trying to get tickets.

meanings.definition: to be in a position where you can see or observe something very well:
examples: He had a ringside seat for the dramas of the Clinton years.

meanings.definition: If you say that someone has a roving eye, you mean that they are always sexually interested in people other than their partner:
examples: By his own admission he had a roving eye and was easily infatuated.
Although he's going out with one of the world's most beautiful women, the actor still has a roving eye.

meanings.definition: If you say that someone has a screw loose, you mean that they behave in a strange way and seem slightly mentally ill.
infml to seem crazy:
examples: Her brother definitely has a screw loose – I don't really trust him.

meanings.definition: to be someone who often criticizes and speaks in a severe way:
examples: Jane has a sharp tongue, so be warned.

meanings.definition: to get angry very easily
to forget things quickly
to refuse to smile and be pleasant to people because you are angry or unhappy about something:
examples: Bullies usually have a sook after they've been called out.
I'm underpaid and I was having a major sook about it at work today.

meanings.definition: If you have a stake in something, it is important to you because you have a personal interest or involvement in it:
examples: Employers have a stake in the training of their staff.
Young people often feel that they don't have a stake in politics.
Everyone has a stake in making sure our legal system is efficient and fair.
Communities along the coast have a stake in what happens to these areas.
Delays in funding are frustrating for everyone who has a stake in the outcomes of the research.

have-a-stick-up-your-arse.name: have a stick up your arse

meanings.definition: a rude phrase meaning to be very serious and easily offended, and always want rules to be obeyed:
examples: She has a stick up her arse and likes lecturing people.
Too many people have sticks up their arses these days.

have-a-stick-up-your-ass.name: have a stick up your ass

meanings.definition: a rude phrase meaning to be very serious and easily offended, and always want rules to be obeyed:
examples: She has a stick up her ass and likes lecturing people.
Too many people have sticks up their asses these days.

have-a-sting-in-the-its-tail.name: have a sting in the/its tail

meanings.definition: If something, such as a story or joke, has a sting in the/its tail, it has a surprising or unpleasant part that only becomes clear at the end.
to be able to smell, taste, or see unpleasant things without feeling ill or upset:
examples: You need to have a very strong stomach to watch some of the surgery scenes.

meanings.definition: to have bad or unhappy experiences:
examples: He's been having a thin time (of it) since his accident.

meanings.definition: to like or dislike something or someone very much:
examples: Ben's got a thing about Harley Davidsons - he's got three of them.
She's got a thing about spiders - she won't go near them.

meanings.definition: to wash your body or a part of it:
examples: I need to have a wash before dinner
She didn't even have time to have a wash before the taxi arrived.
Look at your face! You'd better go and have a wash.
I went upstairs, had a wash, then went to my room.
Would you like to have a wash and a rest now?

meanings.definition: to easily feel ill or upset when you smell, taste, or see something unpleasant

have-a-whale-of-a-time.name: have a whale of a time

meanings.definition: to enjoy yourself very much:
examples: We had a whale of a time on holiday.

have-a-some-etc-say-in.name: have a, some, etc. say in something

meanings.definition: to be involved in making a decision about something:
examples: When he's 18, he'll begin to have a/some say in the running of the family business.
The employees had little/no say in the restructuring of the company.

meanings.definition: to think or believe something, usually based on a guess or on your emotions:
examples: I have a feeling we'll meet again.
I had a feeling it was going to end this way.
She had the feeling he knew more than he was saying.

meanings.definition: to seem to be true:
examples: This story has the ring of truth.

meanings.definition: to be able to arrive at or get inside a place:
examples: The law requires that people with disabilities have full access to public facilities and buildings.
They want to have access to woodlands so they can easily go on country walks.

meanings.definition: to be able to see or speak to a person:
examples: They did not have access to a lawyer.
She's such a superstar that no one has access to her without going through a rigorous vetting process first.

meanings.definition: to be able to use or obtain something:
examples: Millions of people in this country have no access to basic health care.
You are entitled to have access to the personal information collected by your employer.

meanings.definition: to be able to open a computer file, visit a website, etc. in order to look at or change information in it:
examples: They didn't have access to the Internet.
Doctors and pharmacists have access to the patient database.

have-all-the-cares-of-the-world-on-shoul.name: have all the cares of the world on your shoulders

meanings.definition: to be very worried by many different problems:
examples: You look as if you have all the cares of the world on your shoulders.

meanings.definition: to intentionally end a pregnancy:
examples: She had an abortion when she was a teenager.
Supporters of abortion rights said the bill would make it more difficult for some women to have an abortion.

meanings.definition: to urinate or excrete (= pass solid waste) when you do not intend to:
examples: Even a six-year-old can have an accident at night sometimes.

meanings.definition: to do something that is unusual, exciting, and possibly dangerous:
examples: I wanted to see the world and have an adventure.
They have had many adventures together.

meanings.definition: to have a sexual relationship, and especially a secret one with someone you are not married to, or with someone who is married to someone else:
examples: She's having an affair with a married man.
He had an affair with his secretary.

meanings.definition: to have a selfish reason or strong opinion that influences your actions:
examples: The study should be conducted by a firm that has no axe to grind.

meanings.definition: to have a strong personal opinion about something that you want people to accept and that is the reason why you do something:
examples: Environmentalists have no political axe to grind - they just want to save the planet.

meanings.definition: If someone has an ear for music or languages, they are good at hearing, repeating, and understanding these sounds:
examples: She's never had much of an ear for languages.

meanings.definition: to be good at noticing a particular type of thing:
examples: She has an eye for detail.

meanings.definition: to have an ability to notice something:
examples: She has a good eye for detail.

have-an-eye-to-for-the-main-chance.name: have an eye to/for the main chance

meanings.definition: Someone who has an eye to/for the main chance is always ready to use a situation to their own advantage.
to dislike or disapprove of someone or something and let it upset or worry you:
examples: I feel like my dad has an issue with me having a husband with a different religion.
I've never had an issue with the fans saying what they think.
I'm leaving now. Does anyone have an issue with that?
I've never had an issue with any of their other dogs.
It was blatant discrimination and that's something I do have an issue with.

meanings.definition: to need to consider something again, because you are wrong:
examples: If you think I'm going to pay for everything, you've got another think coming.

meanings.definition: infml to need to consider something again, because you made a mistake the first time:
examples: If you expected him to pat you on the back, you had another think coming.

have-another-more-than-one-string-to-bow.name: have another/more than one string to your bow

meanings.definition: to have more than one interest, skill, or resource that you can use if you need to:
examples: I enjoy my work, but I'd like to have another string to my bow in case I lose my job.
She is a multi-talented woman with many strings to her bow.

meanings.definition: to not be able to keep still because you are very excited or worried about something
to be silly and slightly crazy and behave in a confused way
If you have been around the ridges, you have a lot of experience.
to have plans that need great effort, skill, and luck to achieve:
examples: She's got big ideas about starting up her own company.

meanings.definition: to have to be extremely good in order to be as good as the person who had a particular job or position before you:
examples: Whoever gets the job is going to have some pretty big shoes to fill.
We hope she doesn't leave but, if she does, then hers are big boots to fill.

meanings.definition: to have something more important to do
to feel very nervous, usually about something you are going to do:
examples: I had terrible butterflies before I gave that talk in Venice.

meanings.definition: to not have the ability to appreciate (= to enjoy and make good judgments about) music or the way that words sound:
examples: Are you saying that the seven million fans who bought this album have cloth ears?
He occasionally has a cloth ear for how pompous his writing is.

meanings.definition: used to say that someone has a lot of courage and confidence:
examples: He is not without his faults, but the man sure has cojones.
How many people would have the cojones to tell you that to your face?

meanings.definition: to have advanced to an improved or more developed state:
examples: Information technology has come a long way in the last 20 years.

meanings.definition: to have improved greatly:
examples: In the past 20 years, information technology has come a long way.

meanings.definition: If you have company, you are with another person or people:
examples: I'm sorry, I didn't realize you had company.
If I had known we were having company, I would have put on a clean shirt.

meanings.definition: You can say that someone has company if they are not the only person to be in a particular situation:
examples: The two men could soon have company in the race to become the party's new leader.
He now has company on the list of players to have won multiple trophies with the club.

meanings.definition: to be communicating with someone, especially by speaking or writing to them:
examples: The tribe has had hardly any contact with the outside world.
The last time that I had contact with my brother was two years ago.

meanings.definition: to have a lot of money or wealth:
examples: The politicians with the deepest pockets usually win the election.

meanings.definition: If you have designs on something someone else has, you want to get it for yourself, often in ways that are not honest:
examples: He began to have designs on the throne himself.
He suggested that the British had designs on French colonies.

meanings.definition: If you have designs on someone, you want to start a relationship with them, even if they are in a relationship with somene else or do not seem interested in you. :
examples: In the play a lecherous nobleman has designs on a young wife.
He realizes the young man has designs on his brother's wife.

meanings.definition: to have the first right to use something, before anyone else:
examples: I’ve got dibs on the sofa.

meanings.definition: to experience problems:
examples: I was in charge of arrangements and had difficulties from the very first day.
She said she and her husband were having financial difficulties.
Just like other ultra-runners, he has all sorts of difficulties.

meanings.definition: to find it difficult to do something:
examples: She was so tired she had difficulty keeping her eyes open.
He was clearly having difficulty in restraining himself.

meanings.definition: to eat dinner, breakfast, lunch, etc.:
examples: Some people were having dinner outside the restaurant.
Have you had your dinner yet?
I had lunch with a friend this week.
All our guests have breakfast and evening meal in the hotel dining room.

meanings.definition: to have feelings of not being certain about something, especially about how good, possible, or true it is:
examples: Johann had doubts about the long-term viability of the project.
I'm having doubts about his ability to do the job.
Although I was relieved about this upbeat assessment, I must admit I still had my doubts.

meanings.definition: If you have egg on your face, you look stupid because of something that you have done:
examples: This latest scandal has left the government with egg on its face.

meanings.definition: to be very embarrassed because of something you said or did:
examples: He told everyone the deal was happening, and if it falls through now he’ll have egg on his face.

have-eyes-in-the-back-of-head.name: have eyes in the back of your head

meanings.definition: to know everything that is happening around you:
examples: Parents of young children need to have eyes in the back of their heads.

meanings.definition: If you tell someone to have faith, you are encouraging them to stay confident:
examples: Have faith! Everything will work out.

meanings.definition: to be worried about someone or something:
examples: The climbers are a day late returning from the mountain and we are beginning to have fears for their safety.

meanings.definition: to have a bad quality that you keep hidden:
examples: Some of the greatest geniuses in history had feet of clay.

meanings.definition: to know important people who can help you get what you want
to have difficulty doing something:
examples: We had real fun and games trying to bath the dog.

meanings.definition: to look at things very carefully and not miss anything
(of a car) to be able/unable to increase speed quickly:
examples: This car has a very strong road grip and good pickup.
The diesel engine means it has good pickup.
Do petrol engines have better pickup than diesel engines?
The bad pickup may be caused by a fuel injector problem.
As the other vehicles sped by me, I felt embarrassed that my car had such bad pickup.

meanings.definition: If you say that a person has got something there, you mean they have said or discovered an important or interesting thing.
to want something to stop because it is annoying you:
examples: I've had enough - I'm going home.
The coach had had enough. "Get your stuff and go home!" he yelled.
The children had been playing up all day and she'd had enough.
Dad is usually very patient, but even he has had enough.
We've been living with these problems for months now and we've had enough.

have-had-it-up-to-here-with.name: have had it (up to here) with

meanings.definition: to have suffered because of someone or something and to be no longer able to bear him, her, or it:
examples: I've had it up to here with you - get out!
I've had it with foreign holidays.

meanings.definition: (of a machine, etc.) to be in such a bad condition that it is not useful or (of a person, team, etc.) to be doing so badly that they are certain to fail:
examples: I think this computer's had it.
Liverpool have had it for this season.
"I think he's had it," his opponent said, watching him slump to the mat.
I had dropped into fifth place and I thought I'd had it.
We need a new dishwasher. This one's had it.

meanings.definition: to not be willing to continue to deal with someone or something:
examples: I’ve had it with this job – I’m quitting.

meanings.definition: to be much less popular than before:
examples: She sold a lot of books in the 1990s, but she's had her day.

meanings.definition: to have eaten enough:
examples: "Would you like some more stew?" "No thanks, I've had sufficient."
"I've had sufficient," he said politely, discreetly loosening his belt.
Would you like some more dessert or have you had sufficient?
"Any more soup?" "No, I've had sufficient, thank you."
"Have this last bit of pie." "No, I've had sufficient, thanks."

meanings.definition: If you have had the best of something, you have enjoyed the most pleasant part of it, and everything that is left is worse:
examples: I think we've already had the best of the hot weather this summer.
It looks as if it might rain soon - I think we've had the best of the day.
With the pitch deteriorating, it looks as though the England team will have had the best of the weather.
It's pretty clear that he's had the best of his presidency now.

meanings.definition: to have lost your position, importance, or power

have-half-a-mind-a-good-mind-to.name: have half a mind/a good mind to do something

meanings.definition: to think that you might do something, often because something has annoyed you:
examples: I have a good mind to go without him if he's going to be such an idiot!

meanings.definition: If you have heard of someone or something, you know that that person or thing exists:
examples: It's a tiny country that most people have never even heard of.
I'd never heard of him before he won the prize.

meanings.definition: to get extremely angry or upset:
examples: She'll have hysterics when she finds out how much money is missing.

meanings.definition: to have the ability to help yourself manage or achieve something:
examples: He can't cope with difficult situations on his own - he has no inner resources.

meanings.definition: to have difficulty or disagreement with someone or something:
examples: All the people in the study had low self-esteem and had issues with their bodies.
Anna has major issues with her employer.
We should listen more to parents who have issues with their children's education.
We had issues with mechanical parts being difficult to source.
The hotel had some issues with its air conditioning system.

have-it-all-to-play-for.name: have it all to play for

meanings.definition: If someone has it all to play for, the result of a competition or situation is still not known, and they still have the chance to win or be successful. :
examples: We are looking forward to the challenge and we have it all to play for.
You have everything to play for and should trust your own abilities.

meanings.definition: to get advantages from two opposing things:
examples: You can't have it both ways - you either work longer and get paid more or have more leisure time and get paid less.

meanings.definition: infml to deserve what happens to you, esp. something bad:
examples: He got a ticket for speeding, but he had it coming.

meanings.definition: to be determined to harm or criticize someone:
examples: She's always had it in for me.

meanings.definition: infml to be determined to criticize or harm someone:
examples: She’s always had it in for me.

meanings.definition: to have a particular quality or ability:
examples: His speech was really funny - we didn't know he had it in him.

meanings.definition: to possess a particular ability:
examples: His speech was really good – we didn’t know he had it in him to be that funny.

meanings.definition: to have sex:
examples: He was having it off with his friend's wife.

have-it-on-the-highest-authority.name: have it on the highest authority

meanings.definition: to have been told something by someone who knows the truth:
examples: I have it on the highest authority that they are getting a divorce.

meanings.definition: to talk to someone about something they have done that makes you angry, in order to try to solve the problem:
examples: She'd been late for work every morning and I thought I'd better have it out with her.

meanings.definition: to be very worried, upset, or angry about something:
examples: My mother nearly had kittens when I said I was going to buy a motorbike .

meanings.definition: If a story in the news has legs, it will continue for a long time: If something has legs, it can continue to exist and be successful:
examples: This latest scandal has legs - you'll probably still be reading about it in a year's time.
The business has legs.

meanings.definition: to be rich:
examples: I believe her family has money.

meanings.definition: to spend a lot of money on things that are not necessary:
examples: I don't know what her job is but she certainly seems to have money to burn.

meanings.definition: used to say that someone is going to be unpleasantly surprised because something will not be as they want it to be:
examples: I've got news for him, if he thinks he can keep living here free of charge.

meanings.definition: to have no right to do something:
examples: You had no business reading my private letters.

meanings.definition: to not know something:
examples: "Where's Serge?" "I've no idea."
We had no idea when the power might come back on.
"What do you think Bonnie would like for her birthday?" "I have absolutely no idea."
"Why's Dad so grumpy this morning?" "I have no idea."
Molly has no idea how much we miss her.

have-no-option-but-to-do-something.name: have no option (but to do something)

meanings.definition: to have to do a particular thing because there is no possibility of doing anything else:
examples: After her appalling behaviour, we had no option but to dismiss her.
We had no option but to close the entire factory.
She felt she had no option but to resign from her job.
I'm afraid we have no option but to suspend him until the investigation is concluded.
We had no option but to terminate his contract since these unfortunate stories appeared in the press.
I had to leave - I had no option.

meanings.definition: If something has no parallel or is without parallel, there is nothing similar to it or of the same high quality as it:
examples: These beautiful African churches have no parallel in Europe.
Her beauty had no parallel.
The extraordinary carving on this ancient building has no parallel in architecture anywhere.
This ancient body has no parallel in modern society.
Their dedication to the cause was without parallel.
As a teacher, he was without parallel.
She does an outstanding job, and her commitment to the team is without parallel.

meanings.definition: to disapprove of someone and not want to be involved with them:
examples: I have no time for people who are always complaining.

meanings.definition: to refuse to accept, agree with, or support something:
examples: She tried to persuade him to retire, but he would have none of it.

have-nothing-on.name: have nothing on someone or something

meanings.definition: to not be as good as someone or something:
examples: He's a good player, but he's got nothing on his brother.

have-nothing-to-do-with.name: have nothing to do with someone

meanings.definition: to be a matter or subject that someone has no good reason to know about or be involved with:
examples: I wish he wouldn't offer advice on my marriage - it's nothing to do with him.
I certainly wasn't going to interfere - it has got nothing to do with me.
Why is Charlie sticking his nose in? It has nothing to do with him!
Your financial affairs have got nothing to do with me.
What Rachel does in her private life is nothing to do with me.
I don't have to tell her about my relationship. It has nothing to do with her!

meanings.definition: to be in a situation that could improve by doing something and that will not be any worse if you fail at it:
examples: Since I had nothing to lose, I accepted the offer.

have-nothing-to-say-for.name: have nothing to say for yourself

meanings.definition: to not be willing to take part in conversations or express your opinions
to need to do something:
examples: Of course, as a teacher I had authority, but rarely did I have occasion to use it.

have-one-foot-in-the-grave.name: have one foot in the grave

meanings.definition: to be very old and near death
to be old and in bad condition:
examples: That jacket has seen better days. Why don't you get a new one?

meanings.definition: to be old and in bad condition:
examples: This jacket’s seen better days.

meanings.definition: to be extremely stupid:
examples: Don't ask Jack to do anything - he's got shit for brains.

meanings.definition: to have already achieved all that you have the power, ability, or strength to do and to be unable to do more:
examples: He started off the game well but seemed to have shot his bolt by half-time.

meanings.definition: to be directly involved in or affected by something, especially financially:
examples: If people have skin in the game, preventable costs fall.
A debate has been rumbling over how to ensure that lenders have more skin in the game.

meanings.definition: a rude phrase meaning to have someone in a situation where you have complete power over them

have-eating-out-of-hand.name: have someone eating out of your hand

meanings.definition: to easily make someone do or think what you want:
examples: Within two minutes of walking into the classroom, she had the kids eating out of her hand.

have-in-the-palm-of-hand.name: have someone in the palm of your hand

meanings.definition: to have complete control over someone and to be able to make them do anything you want:
examples: He had the audience in the palm of his hand.

meanings.definition: to persuade someone that something is true when it is not, usually as a joke:
examples: That's your new car? You're having me on!

meanings.definition: to put someone in a very difficult situation in which the person has no choice about what they do:
examples: She knows I need the work so she's got me over a barrel in terms of what she pays me.

meanings.definition: to know about and be able to deal with a person or situation
If you have someone to thank for something, that person is responsible or to blame for it:
examples: You have John to thank for this problem.

meanings.definition: to take someone to court for a trial:
examples: He was had up for burglary.

meanings.definition: If you say you will have someone's guts for garters, you mean that you will punish them severely:
examples: If that boy has taken my bike again, I'll have his guts for garters!

meanings.definition: to know a lot about someone and so have an advantage over them:
examples: Don't worry, I've got his number, he doesn't fool me.

have-hanging-round-neck.name: have someone/something hanging round your neck

meanings.definition: to be limited in what you can do by someone or something:
examples: The last thing I want is a couple of kids hanging round my neck!

meanings.definition: If you have something against someone, you dislike them for a reason:
examples: I've nothing against him - I just don't have much in common with him.
She's a great singer. I don't know what Elton 's got against her.
I don't have anything against the police, but I expected them to do more.
I wish she would tell me to my face what she has against me.
They attacked his house repeatedly, but he never found out what they had against him.

have-coming-out-of-ears.name: have something coming out of your ears

meanings.definition: to have more of something than you want or need:
examples: He's going to have money coming out of his ears if this deal comes off.

have-down-to-a-fine-art.name: have something down to a fine art

meanings.definition: to be able to do something very well or quickly, often because you have done it so many times
If you have something going for you, or if something has something going for it, there are certain advantages that will make the end result successful:
examples: They've got a happy marriage, great careers, wonderful kids - in fact they've got everything going for them.

meanings.definition: If you have something going with someone, you are involved in a sexual relationship with them:
examples: Didn't he have something going with one of his students?

meanings.definition: to share interests, experiences, or other characteristics with someone or something:
examples: We don't really have much in common.
The two actors have little in common other than both having Oscars.
When you meet Alice, you'll find that you have a lot in common, including your love of classical music.
In reality, some of their voters have more in common with the more moderate elements in the other party.
Oh, he grew up in Senegal? I may not like him, but we've got that in common, at least.

meanings.definition: to have something well organized or under control: If you have something in hand, you have not yet used it and it is still available:
examples: The police have the situation in hand.
How come there's a problem? I thought you had everything in hand .
I had enough money in hand to buy a new car.

meanings.definition: to have a plan or intention:
examples: Did you have anything in mind for Helen's present?

meanings.definition: to be certain to win or succeed at something:
examples: Last year's winners again have the championship firmly in their pocket.

meanings.definition: If you have something left, you have some remaining after the rest has been used, eaten, etc.:
examples: I never have any money left at the end of the month.
How much time do we have left?
He won't have any friends left if he carries on like this.
I don't think we have any dinner rolls left, sorry.
When he dies, there won't be any speakers of the language left.

meanings.definition: to be able to believe a piece of information because you trust the person who told you it:
examples: I have it on good authority that she's getting married.

meanings.definition: to not be able to stop thinking or talking about one particular thing:
examples: You've got cars on the brain. Can't we talk about something else for a change?

meanings.definition: If you have a difficult situation on your hands, you have to deal with it: to be to blame for something:
examples: If the police carry on like this they'll have a riot on their hands.
She has a battle on her hands if she wants the organization to change.
We have the blood of these people on our hands (= we are responsible for their death or injury).
His death is on the government's hands.

meanings.definition: to be worrying about something:
examples: Paul has a lot on his mind at the moment.

meanings.definition: to have something, usually a large amount of important work, to deal with:
examples: She's got a lot on her plate - especially with two new projects starting this week.
The aid agencies have (more than) enough on their plate without having unnecessary visitors to take care of.

meanings.definition: If you have something on your side, it gives you an advantage when you are trying to achieve something:
examples: I thought I would get the job, but the other person who was being considered for it had experience on his side.

meanings.definition: to have something removed from your body:
examples: You'll have to have that tooth out.
He had his appendix out last week.

meanings.definition: If you have a particular amount of time or money to play with, that amount is available for you to use:
examples: Having only $800 to play with, they bought a second-hand piano.

meanings.definition: used to say that someone has done, made, or achieved something in the past, especially when they have had many successful achievements:
examples: The songwriting pair have more than 3,000 compositions to their credit.
She's a translator with many novels to her credit.
By then, he already had eight gold medals to his credit.
With more than 60 screenplays to his credit, there's a good chance you've seen something he's written.
The band has a huge number of fans considering they have just one album to their credit.

meanings.definition: to have learned or succeeded in something that might be an advantage in the future:
examples: Basic computer skills are a good thing to have under your belt.

meanings.definition: to have secret plans or ideas:
examples: If I know Mark he'll have one or two tricks up his sleeve.

meanings.definition: said if you want to go on a journey and use a particular skill:
examples: The ad in the newspaper read "Have English language skills, will travel".

have-something-nothing-to-show-for.name: have something/nothing to show for something

meanings.definition: If you have something/nothing to show for your work or effort, you have/have not won any advantage from it:
examples: I worked for two weeks, and $50 was all I had to show for it.
I've been trying to write this essay all day and I have nothing to show for it.

meanings.definition: to be likely to steal:
examples: The last person we hired as a cashier turned out to have sticky fingers.

have-the-attention-span-of-a-gnat.name: have the attention span of a gnat

meanings.definition: to be able to pay attention to something for only a very short time before becoming bored or starting to think about something else:
examples: Most teenagers seem to have the attention span of a gnat.
Our governments feel safe in the knowledge that most of us have the attention span of a hyperactive gnat and will soon lose interest.

meanings.definition: to feel sad

have-the-courage-of-convictions.name: have the courage of your convictions

meanings.definition: to be brave and confident enough to do what you believe in:
examples: Although many of his policies were unpopular, he had the courage of his convictions to see them through.
Some of our judges have not had the courage of their convictions to base their rulings only on the evidence.
I'm standing for election because it's about time we had people who have the courage of their convictions running the government.
If you want to see change in the world of medicine, you need to have the courage of your convictions.
She has a great sense of justice and has always had the courage of her convictions.

have-the-decency-good-sense-etc-to-do.name: have the decency, good sense, etc. to do something

meanings.definition: to do one good thing, although you do other bad or silly things:
examples: At least he had the good sense to turn the gas off.
At least she had the decency to apologize.
Let's hope he has the good sense to accept this offer.
You'd think he'd have had the manners to explain his actions.
At least she had the wit to recognize her error and try to make amends.

meanings.definition: If you have the ear of an important person, your ideas are listened to and considered important by that person.
to have the right to speak:
examples: Silence, please, the prime minister has the floor.
Mr Walker, you have the floor, Sir.
No one was inclined to let her have the floor for long.
Finally, it was her turn to have the floor.
The cameras focus on whoever has the floor at that point.

meanings.definition: to have a special position within an organization, or a special relationship with a person that gives you advantages that other people do not have
to finally get an advantage from an argument or disagreement, when it seemed that you would not
to succeed when others thought you would not:
examples: She was fired from the company last year, but she had the last laugh when she was hired by their main rival at twice the salary.

have-the-last-word-on.name: have the last word on something

meanings.definition: to be the person who makes a decision without asking anyone else:
examples: Carol has the last word on whether we go.

meanings.definition: to understand what someone or something is like and to know how to deal with him, her, or it:
examples: I don't think she's under any illusions about her husband - she has the measure of him.

have-the-odds-cards-stacked-against.name: have the odds/cards stacked against you

meanings.definition: to be very unlikely to succeed because you are not in a good position

have-the-patience-of-a-saint.name: have the patience of a saint

meanings.definition: to always be calm and never allow anything to upset you

have-the-wind-at-back.name: have the wind at your back

meanings.definition: to be in a good situation in which you can succeed:
examples: The president has the wind at his back on this issue.

have-the-world-at-feet.name: have the world at your feet

meanings.definition: to be extremely successful and admired by a large number of people:
examples: Five years after her debut, the diminutive star of the Royal Ballet has the world at her feet.

meanings.definition: to be easily/not easily upset by criticism:
examples: I don't worry about what he says - I have a very thick skin.

meanings.definition: to have nothing to do:
examples: Gina has some time on her hands, so she is taking a college course.

meanings.definition: If you have time, you have enough time to do something:
examples: We don't have much time before the train leaves.
Do you have time for a quick drink after work?
I'd like to learn to sail, but I don't have the time (= I am too busy).
I don't have time to go to the shops today.
I mean, who has time to cook from scratch every evening?
I'd meet you for lunch but I'm afraid I don't have time today.

meanings.definition: to have nothing to do for a particular period:
examples: We've got some time to kill before we leave - do you want to have some coffee.

meanings.definition: (used with the infinitive form of another verb) to need to or be forced to; must:
examples: I have to go to Vermont tomorrow.

meanings.definition: to be about something:
examples: My question has to do with last week’s assignment.

meanings.definition: to move in a very awkward way when dancing:
examples: When we danced together, I discovered he had two left feet.

have-what-it-takes-to.name: have what it takes (to do something)

meanings.definition: to have the qualities or character needed to be successful:
examples: She doesn’t have a college degree, but I think she has what it takes to do the job.

meanings.definition: to speak angrily to someone because they have done something wrong :
examples: Her father would have had words with her about that.
At the end of the game I had words with the referee but I immediately apologized afterwards.
The assailant had words with the victim and his friends before hitting him.
He did that? Well, I'll have to have some words with him.

meanings.definition: If you have yet to do something, you have not done it:
examples: They have yet to make a decision.
Peters has yet to choose his next project.
She has yet to reach her full potential as an athlete.
We've yet to receive an apology.
They have yet to announce any plans.
I've verbally agreed to do the work but I've yet to receive a contract.

meanings.definition: to have a lot or more than enough of something bad:
examples: We certainly have our share of problems at the moment.
She's had her fair share of tragedies in her life.

have-back-to-against-the-wall.name: have your back to/against the wall

meanings.definition: to have very serious problems that limit the ways in which you can act:
examples: He owes money to everyone - he really has his back to the wall now.

have-business-sensible-etc-head-on.name: have your business, sensible, etc. head on

meanings.definition: used for saying that you are considering something from a particular way of thinking:
examples: I had my sensible head on that morning and knew we couldn't afford to buy the car.

have-cake-and-eat-it-too.name: have your cake and eat it (too)

meanings.definition: to have or do two good things at the same time that are impossible to have or do at the same time:
examples: You can't have your cake and eat it - if you want more local services, you can't expect to pay less tax.

meanings.definition: to do or get two good things at the same time, esp. things that are not usually possible to have together:
examples: I worked at home so I could raise my family and still earn money – I guess I wanted to have my cake and eat it too.

meanings.definition: to get an opportunity to give your opinion on something or to explain your actions after they have been criticized:
examples: She was determined to get her day in court and the TV interview would give it to her.

meanings.definition: to disagree with someone on one or more matters:
examples: We’ve had our differences, but we've learned how to work together very well.

meanings.definition: to have seen something that you want and intend to get:
examples: She's had her eye on a bike for some time.

meanings.definition: to admire and want to have something:
examples: She has her eye on that new bike at Miller’s Toys.

have-feet-on-the-ground.name: have your feet on the ground

meanings.definition: to be practical and able to take care of yourself:
examples: Don’t worry about Kerry – she’s a smart girl who has her feet on the ground.

have-finger-on-the-trigger.name: have your finger on the trigger

meanings.definition: used to say that someone is ready and prepared to do something, especially something violent:
examples: They have their finger on the trigger to start a nuclear war.

have-fingers-in-the-till.name: have your fingers in the till

meanings.definition: to steal money from the place where you work
to be so busy that you do not have time to do anything else:
examples: I'd love to help but I've got my hands full organizing the school play.

have-head-buried-stuck-in-a-book.name: have your head (buried/stuck) in a book

meanings.definition: to be reading:
examples: Rose always has her head buried in a book.

have-head-stuck-up-own-ass.name: have your head (stuck) up your (own) ass

meanings.definition: an offensive phrase meaning to not pay attention to what is happening; to behave in a silly or stupid way:
examples: He admitted that a lot of his co-workers had their heads up their asses.
He strolls along as relaxed as can be, basically with his head up his ass.
If you deny this, you have your head in your ass.

have-head-in-the-clouds.name: have your head in the clouds

meanings.definition: used to say that someone's ideas or plans are not practical or reasonable, or that they are thinking about something that is not important or not connected with what needs to be done :
examples: He was often criticized for not being realistic, for having his head in the clouds.
Some visionaries have their heads in the clouds and can’t explain simple concepts without getting sidetracked.
It's possible that your buyer actually has their head in the clouds and doesn't have the money.
He's a spiritual man, but not a man with his head in the clouds — he's also a scientist.
I was aware of what was going on. I didn't walk around with my head in the clouds.
Your heart is in the right place but your head is in the clouds.

have-your-head-screwed-on-the-right-way.name: have your head screwed on (the right way)

meanings.definition: to be practical and wise:
examples: Ask Lois to help - she's got her head screwed on the right way.

have-head-up-arse.name: have your head up your arse

meanings.definition: an offensive phrase meaning to not pay attention to what is happening; to behave in a silly or stupid way:
examples: This guy has his head up his arse.
I think too many people have their heads up their arse on this issue.

meanings.definition: to try to upset or harm someone because you dislike them

have-nose-in-a-book.name: have your nose in a book

meanings.definition: to be reading:
examples: She always has her nose in a book.

meanings.definition: to have a large choice available:
examples: The plane was fairly empty so we had our pick of seats.
We haven't sold any of the puppies yet, so you can have your pick of the litter.
As a successful movie star, he had his pick of glamorous girlfriends.
This year you'll have your pick of chunky knits and cashmere.
With those qualifications, she will have her pick of great jobs.

meanings.definition: If a woman has her tubes tied, she has a medical operation in which her fallopian tubes are closed to stop her eggs being released so that she cannot become pregnant.
to think and react quickly when something dangerous or difficult happens unexpectedly:
examples: She managed to keep her wits about her and escaped unharmed.

have-work-cut-out-for.name: have your work cut out (for you)

meanings.definition: to have something very difficult to do:
examples: She'll really have her work cut out to finish all those reports by the end of the week.

meanings.definition: to have something difficult to do:
examples: If she has to finish that report by tomorrow, she has her work cut out for her.

meanings.definition: to be sometimes very good or successful:
examples: This album may not be as good as their last one but it has its moments.

meanings.definition: an ordinary person who does something brave in order to try and stop a crime

have-carry-bear-feel-the-weight-of-the-w.name: have/carry/bear/feel the weight of the world on your shoulders

meanings.definition: to have a lot of things to feel worried or sad about:
examples: Even when I was 18 with no responsibilities, I acted like I had the weight of the world on my shoulders.
We don't feel the weight of the world on our shoulders the way mothers do.
He is a sad-faced young man who seems to carry the weight of the world on his shoulders.
If you have a stressful desk job with the weight of the world on your shoulders, you could probably benefit from a neck massage.

meanings.definition: to be or become effective, organized, and skilful:
examples: One of these days I'll get my shit together.

have-get-snout-in-the-trough.name: have/get your snout in the trough

meanings.definition: to have or get a share of a supply of money or some other advantage that people eagerly and sometimes dishonestly take:
examples: The council had been handing out grants indiscriminately, and people were hurrying to get their snouts in the trough.

meanings.definition: to be in a strong position when you are competing with someone else because you have all the advantages:
examples: In a situation like this, it's the big companies who hold all the aces.

meanings.definition: to be the person or group that has the most power in a situation:
examples: During the last decade the right wing of the party has held the whip hand.

meanings.definition: to be ready to think quickly in a situation and react to things that you are not expecting:
examples: Cycling is potentially very dangerous in the city - you have to keep your wits about you.

have-keep-feet-on-the-ground.name: have/keep your feet on the ground

meanings.definition: to be very practical and see things as they really are

have-keep-finger-on-the-pulse.name: have/keep your finger on the pulse

meanings.definition: to be/stay familiar with the most recent changes or improvements:
examples: The situation changes daily, so you need to keep your finger on the pulse.

meanings.definition: to wait before making a choice:
examples: I'm going to keep my options open while I find out about studying abroad.

meanings.definition: to know something so well that you can say or do it without having to try or think:
examples: I'd given the talk so many times I had it down pat.

meanings.definition: to know something so well that you can say or do it without having to try or think:
examples: I'd given the talk so many times I had it off pat.

meanings.definition: to have a life in which you are protected too much and experience very little danger, excitement, or change:
examples: Until going to college, she had led a very sheltered life.

meanings.definition: to attempt to do something although you are not likely to be very successful:
examples: I'd never tried snorkelling before but I had a stab at it while I was in Greece.

have-put-head-on-the-block.name: have/put your head on the block

meanings.definition: to risk a bad thing happening to you by doing something or helping someone:
examples: I'm not going to put my head on the block for you.

meanings.definition: a rude phrase meaning to pass the contents of the bowels out of the body
to have a quick look:
examples: Let's take a gander at your new car, then.
I love having a gander at other people's homes - it gives me ideas.
Can I take a gander at your new shed, Mike?
I was walking by the new restaurant on Green Street so I thought I'd take a gander at the menu.
Why don't you call in and have a gander at our new kitchen?

have-take-a-notion-to.name: have/take a notion to do something

meanings.definition: to suddenly want to do something:
examples: I had a notion to write them a letter.

meanings.definition: to look at something for a short time:
examples: If I'm passing by I might take a peek at the new premises.
We were allowed to take a peek at the new season's collection.
I had a peek in his diary while he was out of the room.
Do you mind if we take a peek at the kittens?
It would be lovely to have a peek at the windmill while we're here.

meanings.definition: to have the most important position in a group of things:
examples: A portrait of his grandfather takes pride of place in the entrance hall.

meanings.definition: to stop work, in order to do something else:
examples: I asked my boss if I could have some time off from work to go to the dentist.
He took time off from work to care for his son.
She took time off in the mid-'80s to raise her daughter.
If you need to take some time off, just let me know.
Earlier that year he'd taken time off sick because of stress.
I haven't had any time off this year.
She'd had some time off to deal with her depression.

meanings.definition: to become very angry or worried, often shouting a lot:
examples: She'll throw a fit when she sees the mess you've made.

have-want-nothing-to-do-with.name: have/want nothing to do with someone/something

meanings.definition: to have or want no connection or influence with someone or something:
examples: We are nothing to do with the firm that has the offices next door.
In the evening he likes to read books and articles that have nothing to do with his work.
Problems like these have nothing to do with personal hygiene.
Is the bakery anything to do with the vegan cafe on that road?
After what that company did to me, I want nothing to do with them.
Politicians want nothing to do with the latest securities scandal to rock Washington.

meanings.definition: to receive more votes in an election than any other person or party, but not more than the total number of votes that the other people or parties have received:
examples: He won a 48 percent plurality of the vote rather than an outright majority.
There are five districts where Republicans have a plurality of voters.
The conservatives have a plurality in this Congress, but just barely.
The person who wins a plurality in the primary will become the nominee.
His party won a plurality in the governing assembly last year.

meanings.definition: a safe or peaceful place:
examples: The garden was a haven from the noise and bustle of the city.
They wanted to provide safe havens for the refugees.

meanings.definition: an area of water next to the coast where ships and boats can shelter, or a small port:
examples: These days the port is mainly used as a haven for small fishing boats.
He sailed the boat straight to the nearest pirate haven to recruit a real crew.

meanings.definition: a safe or peaceful place
a safe place, especially a country where you can keep your money protected:
examples: The island's tax regulations are so lax that it has become a haven for owners of offshore companies.

meanings.definition: short form of have not:
examples: I haven't been to Australia.

meanings.definition: contraction of have not:
examples: I haven’t finished eating.

meanings.definition: a bag, often made from strong, rough cloth, with one or two shoulder straps
a small passage inside a bone that carries blood vessels and nerve fibres:
examples: Mammals have minute channels for blood vessels known as Haversian canals.
At approximately four weeks after fixation, haversian canals proliferate along the longitudinal axis of the bone.

meanings.definition: a small passage inside a bone that carries blood vessels and nerve fibres, and the layer of bone that surrounds it :
examples: The whole of the bone is permeated by a system of blood vessels running through the bony canals in the centres of the Haversian systems.
Concentric lamellar bone is bone forming parts of the haversian system, with haversian canals in the centre.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         have
despite what has just been said:
examples: He forgets most things, but having said that, he always remembers my birthday.

meanings.definition: confusion and lack of order, especially causing damage or trouble:
examples: The storm wreaked (= caused) havoc in the garden, uprooting trees and blowing a fence down.
The delay played (= caused) havoc with their travel arrangements.

meanings.definition: confusion and lack of order that result in damage or trouble:
examples: The storm created complete havoc in the park.

meanings.definition: a national park (= a large area of land protected by the government because of its natural beauty or because it has a special history) in the US state of Hawaii:
examples: Hawaiʻi Volcanoes National Park draws thousands of people daily, with a visitors center and lodge near the crater rim.
Scientists conduct research in Hawaiʻi Volcanoes National Park to practice for Mars landings.

meanings.definition: a group of islands in the Pacific Ocean that is a state of the US :
examples: She returned to Hawaii in the summer.
Hawaii is the only state that is an archipelago.

meanings.definition: the largest island in the group of Pacific islands that forms the US state of Hawaii:
examples: We flew to Hawaiʻi then took a boat to Molokai.
She lives in Captain Cook on the west side of Hawaiʻi Island.

meanings.definition: someone from the US state of Hawaii:
examples: The party was thrown by a slightly eccentric Hawaiian.
Obama says his wife is the best hula hooper he knows. And coming from a Hawaiian, that's a pretty big compliment.

meanings.definition: a language spoken in Hawaii:
examples: The place is called Pihanakalani in Hawaiian.
She learned Hawaiian at home with her parents.

meanings.definition: belonging or relating to the US state of Hawaii or its people or language:
examples: Koa was Hawaiian and knew a lot about kukui nuts.
Five restaurants in San Francisco serve Hawaiian food.
"Mahalo" is the Hawaiian word for "thank you".

meanings.definition: a loose, informal shirt with colourful patterns of tropical flowers, trees, or fruit on it:
examples: Classic island wear might consist of shorts, a Hawaiian shirt, and flip-flops.
The bar is very informal, with all the employees wearing Hawaiian shirts.

meanings.definition: a loose, informal shirt with colorful patterns on it
a type of large bird that catches small birds and animals for food
a person who strongly supports the use of force in political relationships rather than discussion or other more peaceful solutions
to sell goods informally in public places:
examples: On every street corner there were traders hawking their wares.

meanings.definition: a type of large bird that catches small birds and animals for food
to sell goods in public places by calling out to people:
examples: She was hawking flowers at the parking lot exit.

meanings.definition: someone who believes that the government should take strong action in controlling the national budget, inflation, etc.:
examples: The hawks on the committee are worried that 6 per cent growth could trigger inflation.
a budget/deficit/inflation hawk

meanings.definition: to sell goods in the street or a public place:
examples: Street vendors hawk tea, watches, T-shirts, chickens, and just about everything else.
Most major businesses hawk their wares on the Net.

meanings.definition: to try to interest a person or company in a product, idea, etc.:
examples: He has written a guide to finances which he plans to hawk around to all the major publishers.

meanings.definition: a brand name for a technology used in many sports to help the officials to make decisions, for example to show whether a ball is inside or outside a line in the playing area:
examples: They are using Hawk-Eye for the first time in this tournament.
Hawkeye allows umpires to use ball tracking technology to decide whether the ball would have hit the stumps.

meanings.definition: Someone who is hawk-eyed watches and notices everything that happens:
examples: Hawk-eyed store detectives stood by the doors.

meanings.definition: a type of radiation (= energy from heat or light that you cannot see ) that should be produced by a black hole (= a region in space where gravity is so strong that nothing, not even light, can escape):
examples: When a black hole evaporates, the Hawking radiation it emits is not random.
Hawking radiation is named after the famous black hole theorist Stephen Hawking.

meanings.definition: supporting the use of force in political relationships rather than discussion or other more peaceful solutions:
examples: The president is hawkish on foreign policy.
Such opposition only hardened their hawkish views.

meanings.definition: Hawkish features are similar to those of a hawk (= a type of large bird that catches small birds and animals for food):
examples: He has dark eyebrows and deep-set, hawkish eyes.
She has a long hawkish nose.

meanings.definition: watching something very closely or with a lot of attention:
examples: He watched with hawkish attention as Giovanni danced with his wife.
She always keeps a hawkish eye on costs.

meanings.definition: in a way that supports the use of force in political relationships rather than discussion or other more peaceful solutions:
examples: The hawkishly conservative pundit believed that the country should exact retaliation against the regime for human rights abuses.
The candidate spoke hawkishly about the country's foreign policy and was in favour of expanding its military presence through the world.

meanings.definition: like a hawk (= a type of large bird that catches small birds and animals for food), especially in the way someone or something watches very closely and with a lot of attention:
examples: The dog was watching our table hawkishly, waiting for someone to drop a morsel of food on the floor.
Our account manager hawkishly keeps track of the company's money and flags any expenses that do not have a receipt.

meanings.definition: one of many different wild plants with yellow or orange flowers that can cause serious problems in areas where they do not grow naturally:
examples: Hawkweed is already rampant in parts of the wildlife refuge.
Many hawkweeds reproduce from fruits formed without fertilization having occurred.

meanings.definition: a strong, thick rope, often made of steel
a type of small tree with thorns (= sharp points), white or pink flowers in spring, and small, red fruits in autumn
grass that is cut and dried and used as animal food
tall grass that is cut, dried, and used as animal food or as covering material:

meanings.definition: an illness like a cold, caused by pollen:
examples: She gets really bad hay fever.
hay fever sufferers

meanings.definition: a physical reaction to the pollen of plants which causes some people to have problems with their eyes, nose, throat, and lungs
grass or other green plants that are cut and stored, without being completely dried first, and used to feed cows in winter. It is similar to, but slightly drier than, silage.
especially in boxing, a very powerful, and sometimes uncontrolled, punch (= hit):
examples: In the 10th round, both fighters traded haymakers for the full three minutes.

meanings.definition: a social event in which a group of people go for a ride in an open vehicle filled with hay
a social event in which a group of people take a ride in an open vehicle filled with hay
a large, tall pile of hay in a field
a large pile of hay in a field
something that is dangerous and likely to cause damage:

meanings.definition: an area of a golf course (= area of land used for playing golf) that provides an obstacle (= something that blocks you so that movement, going forward, or action is made more difficult):
examples: In golf, hazards are just another part of the game.
The golf course now features the most dramatic water hazards.

meanings.definition: to risk doing something, especially making a guess, suggestion, etc.:
examples: I wouldn't like to hazard a guess.

meanings.definition: to risk doing something that might cause harm to someone or something else:
examples: The policy hazarded the islands and put the lives of the inhabitants at risk.

meanings.definition: something dangerous and likely to cause damage:
examples: a health/fire hazard

meanings.definition: to risk making a guess or suggestion:
examples: She wouldn’t hazard a guess about the meaning of the word.

meanings.definition: something that is dangerous and likely to cause a problem or damage:
examples: an environmental/health/fire hazard
When it comes to investments, research shows that women are more likely to weigh up potential hazards than their male counterparts.

meanings.definition: one of the orange lights at the front and back of a car that turn on and off repeatedly to warn other drivers of danger:
examples: The car had its hazard lights flashing.

a hazardous journey/occupation

meanings.definition: dangerous and involving risk, especially to someone's health:

meanings.definition: in a way that is dangerous:
examples: The plane came hazardously close to clipping the power lines as it approached the runway for landing.
