meanings.definition: something such as heat or smoke in the air that makes it less clear, so that it is difficult to see well:
examples: The road through the desert shimmered in the haze.
I saw her through a haze of cigarette smoke.

meanings.definition: to play tricks on someone, especially a new person in a fraternity or sorority
fog caused by water, smoke, or dust, or an effect of heat that prevents things being seen clearly:
examples: A brownish haze hung over the field.

If the sky hazes over, the air becomes less clear, especially because of heat:
examples: The sky began to haze over in the afternoon.

meanings.definition: a small tree that produces nuts that can be eaten
a greenish-brown or yellowish-brown colour
(especially of eyes) greenish-brown or yellowish-brown in colour
a small tree that produces edible nuts
(esp. of eyes) a green-brown or yellow-brown color
a nut with a hard, brown shell. Hazelnuts come from the hazel tree.
in a way that is not clearly remembered or noticed:
examples: She only hazily remembered her previous visit.

meanings.definition: in a way that cannot be seen very clearly, especially because of heat:
examples: The sun rose hazily behind the palm trees.
The streets and monuments of Athens stretched hazily away to the mountains.

meanings.definition: the activity of playing tricks on someone, especially a new person in a fraternity or sorority (= a social organization for university students):
examples: Ten fraternity members had their heads shaved during hazing last week.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for hazardous material: a dangerous substance:
examples: Each volunteer was given a disposable white hazmat suit (= a suit that protects against dangerous substances)
Over the past two weeks, hazmat crews have been flooded with anthrax false alarms.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for hazardous materials suit: a piece of clothing that covers the entire body and other clothing, worn to protect against dangerous substances such as poisonous chemicals or infectious viruses:
examples: Paramedics arrived dressed in hazmat suits and wearing masks.
Each volunteer was given a disposable white hazmat suit.

meanings.definition: Hazy air or weather is not clear, especially because of heat:
examples: hazy sunshine
the hazy days of summer

meanings.definition: not remembering things clearly:
examples: hazy memories of childhood

meanings.definition: not clear because of haze (= fog):
examples: a hazy day/sky

meanings.definition: Hazy also means not remembering things clearly:
examples: I’m hazy about what happened after the accident.

meanings.definition: written abbreviation for haemoglobin
abbreviation for hepatitis B virus: the virus responsible for hepatitis B (= a serious liver disease):
examples: HBV is transmitted in the blood and other body fluids.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for highest common factor: the highest number that a set of two or more different numbers can be divided by exactly

         hydrochlorofluorocarbon  : a type of gas used especially in aerosols (= containers that force out liquids in very small drops)
abbreviation for human-computer interface: the part of a computer system, for example what you see on the screen, that allows a person to use a computer
abbreviation for hepatitis C virus: the virus responsible for hepatitis C, which produces long-lasting liver disease
abbreviation for high-definition: used to describe a system for showing very clear pictures on a television or computer screen or for producing very clear sound:
examples: The series was shot entirely in HD.
HDTV sets

meanings.definition: abbreviation for high definition: used to describe a system for showing very clear pictures on a television or computer screen or for producing very clear sound:
examples: HD DVD/radio
The picture quality of HD-ready sets varies depending on the model.
As more people buy HDTV sets, more programming will be needed in HD format.
HD broadcast/channel/resolution

meanings.definition: abbreviation for hard disk drive: a device inside or connected to a computer for storing computer programs and information:
examples: This is how to check how much space is remaining on your HDD.
The server had 4 HDDs.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for hard disk drive: used to describe equipment that uses the same type of magnetic system for storing information as is used by a computer:
examples: HDD camcorders

meanings.definition: abbreviation for human development index: a measurement of the development of a country that is based on the health, education, and standard of living of the people who live there:
examples: Australia rates very high on the HDI.
According to the HDI, global inequality has fallen sharply since 1950.
We're lucky to live somewhere that scores pretty well in the HD Index.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for High-Definition Multimedia Interface: a brand name for equipment used for sending uncompressed digital signals from a sound or video source to a computer, television, etc. screen :
examples: I just bought two HDMI cables.
My TV set doesn't even have an HDMI port.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for High-Definition Multimedia Interface: a system that allows very clear sound and pictures to be produced by television and other electronic equipment:
examples: HDMI can make a significant difference in a home theater system.
This model has two HDMI inputs for connecting an HD box and a DVD player.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for high dynamic range: the ability of screens on televisions, etc. to show very clear images with a wide range of natural colours, and a lot of contrast between the bright parts of the image and the dark parts:
examples: HDR TV/technology

meanings.definition: abbreviation for high-definition television (= a type of television that shows clear, high-quality pictures on a wider screen than standard television):
examples: Consumers have bought 10 million HDTVs but have found little to watch.

meanings.definition: HDTV is also the programs you watch or the business of broadcasting them:
examples: There’s no HDTV on our local channels.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for high-definition television (= a type of television that shows clear, high-quality pictures on a wider screen than standard television):
examples: Consumers have bought 10 million HDTVs but have found little to watch.

meanings.definition: HDTV is also the programs you watch or the business of broadcasting them:
examples: There’s no HDTV on our local channels.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for high dependency unit: the part of a hospital that provides a high level of care and treatment for patients who are seriously ill or who have just had a major operation:
examples: After some major operations, you may be taken to the HDU or ICU.
The absence of an HDU in hospitals taking acute surgical cases was detrimental to patient care.

meanings.definition: used as the subject of a verb to refer to a man, boy, or male animal that has already been mentioned:
examples: Don't ask Andrew, he won't know.
There's no need to be frightened - he's a very friendly dog.

meanings.definition: used to refer to a person whose gender is not known or not important in that situation:
examples: The modern traveller can go where he likes.
As soon as the baby is born, he'll start to take an interest in the world around him.

meanings.definition: a male:
examples: How can you tell whether the fish is a he or a she?

meanings.definition: the male being spoken about, who has already been mentioned:
examples: Don’t ask Andrew, he won’t know.

meanings.definition: He is also used to refer to a person whose sex is not known:
examples: Today a person can travel anywhere he likes.

meanings.definition: used to describe a situation in which two people involved in an event make different claims about what happened, and no one else was present who can support either claim:
examples: Rape cases are often thought to come down to he said, she said.
It was a he said, she said situation, and administrators accepted the word of a student over that of one of their own faculty members.

he-who-fights-and-runs-away-lives-to-fig.name: he who fights and runs away, lives to fight another day

meanings.definition: used to say that it can be a good and acceptable decision to leave a difficult situation

he-who-laughs-last-laughs-longest-best.name: he who laughs last, laughs longest/best

meanings.definition: said to emphasize that the person who has control of a situation in the end is most successful, even if other people had seemed originally to have an advantage

he-who-pays-the-piper-calls-the-tune.name: he who pays the piper calls the tune.

meanings.definition: said to emphasize that the person who is paying someone to do something can decide how it should be done
short form of he had:
examples: He'd already spent all his money by the second day of the trip.

meanings.definition: short form of he would:
examples: He'd be able to do it, if anyone could.

meanings.definition: contraction of he had or he would:
examples: He’d (= He had) already spent all his money by the second day of the trip.
He’d (= He would) be able to do it if he would just try.

meanings.definition: short form of he will:
examples: He'll be there, don't worry.

meanings.definition: contraction of he will or he shall:
examples: I’m sure he’ll help you if he can.

meanings.definition: short form of he is:
examples: He's a great guy.

meanings.definition: short form of he has:

meanings.definition: contraction of he is or he has:
examples: He’s (= He is) late.

meanings.definition: a man who is very strong and who likes to show everyone how strong he is
said if you think someone should have to suffer because of their bad behaviour:
examples: After all the harm she's done, she deserves whatever she gets.

meanings.definition: the part of the body above the neck where the eyes, nose, mouth, ears, and brain are:
examples: Put this hat on to keep your head warm.
He banged his head on the car as he was getting in.
She thought for a while, and then nodded her head (= showed her agreement).
I asked her if I could go inside, but she shook her head (= showed her disagreement).

meanings.definition: a person or animal when considered as a unit:
examples: Dinner will cost £20 a/per head (= for each person).
I did a quick head count (= calculated how many people there were).
They own a hundred head of cattle (= 100 animals).

meanings.definition: a measure of length or height equal to the size of a head:
examples: Her horse won by a head.
Paul is a head taller than Andrew.

meanings.definition: the mind and mental abilities:
examples: I went for a walk to clear my head.

Once she gets an idea into her head she won't give up.
I can't get that tune out of my head (= I cannot stop hearing the tune in my mind).
I can't get her out of my head (= I cannot stop thinking about her).
We need to find a practical person with a head for business.
Harriet has a good head for figures (= she is very good at calculating numbers).

meanings.definition: someone in charge of or leading an organization, group, etc.:
examples: the head of the History department
the head chef
his first season as head coach

a

the top part or beginning of something:

the head of the page

meanings.definition: the larger end of a nail, hammer, etc.
the top part of a plant where a flower or leaves grow:
examples: a head of lettuce

meanings.definition: the layer of white bubbles on top of beer after it has been poured
the upper part of a river, where it begins
the top part of a spot when it contains pus (= yellow liquid)
the part of a tape or video recorder (= machine for recording sound or pictures) that touches the tape to record and play music, speech, etc.
the main part of the phrase, to which the other parts are related
a narrow area of high land that sticks out into the sea:
examples: the chalk cliffs around Beachy Head

meanings.definition: to go in a particular direction:

meanings.definition: to be in charge of a group or organization:

meanings.definition: to be at the front or top of something:
examples: The royal carriage headed the procession.

meanings.definition: to hit a ball with your head:
examples: Rooney headed the ball into the back of the net.

meanings.definition: a person with a particular strong interest or addiction:
examples: a crack-head (= someone who depends on the drug crack)

meanings.definition: the part of the body that contains the eyes, nose, mouth, ears, and the brain:

meanings.definition: A head is also the approximate length of a head used as a measurement:
examples: Carlos is almost a head taller than Manuel.

meanings.definition: the mind and mental abilities:

Someone offered me the ticket, and your name popped into my head.

meanings.definition: a position or part at the top, front, or beginning:
examples: They were early enough to get a place at the head of the line.

meanings.definition: The head of a plant is the top part where a flower or leaves grow:

meanings.definition: someone who leads or is in charge of an organization or group, or this position of leadership:
examples: In 1990 he was made head of the engineering division.

meanings.definition: to go in a particular direction:
examples: I was heading out the door when the phone rang.

fig. He’s headed for trouble if he gets involved with her.

meanings.definition: to lead or control something:
examples: She headed a group that defended the senator against detractors.

meanings.definition: to be at the top, front, or beginning of something:
examples: Currently, her name heads the list of candidates for the job.

meanings.definition: main or most important:

meanings.definition: a person who is in charge of a team, department, or an organization:

meanings.definition: one person considered as a unit:
examples: The region saw incomes per head fall by an average 4 per cent a year over the past decade.

meanings.definition: to lead or manage a team, department, organization, etc.:
examples: After five years in the US office, he returns to London to head the finance department.

meanings.definition: to move in a particular direction or towards a particular result:

meanings.definition: to put a title at the top of a page, column, etc.:
examples: The report was headed "confidential".

meanings.definition: If someone or something is head and shoulders above other people or things, he, she, or it is a lot better than them:
examples: There's no competition - they're head and shoulders above the rest.

meanings.definition: much better than other people or things:
examples: Natasha is head and shoulders above the other dancers in her age group.

meanings.definition: a boy or girl who often represents his or her school on formal occasions:

meanings.definition: the cook who is in charge of the preparation of food in a restaurant or hotel, telling other kitchen workers what to do, deciding what dishes should be on the menu, checking the dishes before they are served, etc.:

meanings.definition: a cold when your nose feels very blocked
the exact number of people in a place, or the act of counting them:

meanings.definition: if share prices or currencies head down, they lose value:

meanings.definition: in basketball, a head movement that makes your opponent think you are going to move in a particular direction when you are really going to move in a different direction

an act that is designed to confuse your opponents about your plans or intentions:

meanings.definition: with the head going first
to go towards a thing or place:
examples: I headed for the door.

meanings.definition: If you are heading for a bad situation, you are likely to experience it soon, because of your own actions or behaviour:
examples: They're heading for disaster if they're not careful.

meanings.definition: If someone has their head in the game, they are paying very careful attention to what they are doing:

meanings.definition: a very small insect that lives and lays its eggs in people's hair:

meanings.definition: the official leader of a country, often someone who has few or no real political powers
to start a journey or leave a place:

meanings.definition: to force someone or something to change direction:

meanings.definition: to prevent a difficult or unpleasant situation from happening:

meanings.definition: to block someone's movement by getting in front of the person:
examples: Police tried to head off the bank robbers at the next exit.

meanings.definition: to take action to stop something from happening:

meanings.definition: the most important office of an organization or company, or the people working there:

meanings.definition: completely in love

meanings.definition: a part attached to a chair, especially a seat in a car, that supports the head and stops it from moving too far back:

meanings.definition: a shop that sells equipment for smoking cannabis and tobacco, and often New Age products:

meanings.definition: to stop something from happening:

meanings.definition: to lead or control a group, part of a company, etc.:

meanings.definition: to lead or manage a team, department, organization, etc.:

meanings.definition: the advantage of beginning before others in a competition or other situation:

A head-on accident is one in which the fronts of two vehicles hit each other:
examples: The car crossed the road and hit a truck head-on.

meanings.definition: direct or directly:
examples: We should have sat down and addressed the issues head-on.

meanings.definition: If two vehicles hit head-on, their fronts hit each other directly:
examples: The head-on collision left three people dead.

examples: Two drivers were killed in a head-on collision between a car and a taxi last night.

meanings.definition: involving a direct competition between two people or teams:

meanings.definition: opposing each other in direct competition:

meanings.definition: involving two people or groups that are competing directly against each other:

head-to-head competition

meanings.definition: involving two people discussing something directly with each other, especially in order to see which person seems better:

meanings.definition: if two or more people or companies compete, go, etc. head to head, they compete directly with each other:

meanings.definition: a situation, meeting, programme, etc. in which two people discuss something directly with each other, especially in order to see which person seems the best:

meanings.definition: in a computer game, the part of the screen that shows information such as the player's score, how much time they have left, etc., which the player can easily see while playing the game:

meanings.definition: the floor of a fireplace, and often also the area in front of it
enthusiastically, energetically, and often loudly:

meanings.definition: the central part of a country or area:

meanings.definition: the part of a country that is most important for a particular activity, or where a political party has the most support:

meanings.definition: the central or most important part of an area:

meanings.definition: an area where a large number of people support a particular political party and vote for it in an election:

meanings.definition: cruel and not worrying about other people:

meanings.definition: one of the four suits (= groups) of playing cards, the symbol for which is the shape used to represent the heart as a symbol of love

meanings.definition: a famous man, often a singer or an actor, who is attractive to many women

meanings.definition: a record of actions or events that have happened often over a period of time:

meanings.definition: very emotional and energetic, but not sincere or without real meaning:

meanings.definition: (of behavior) showing a lot of emotion in order to persuade others or attract attention:

meanings.definition: in a way that is very emotional and energetic, but is not sincere or lacks real meaning:

meanings.definition: very emotional and energetic behaviour that is not sincere and has no real meaning:

meanings.definition: loud, emotional behavior that does not seem sincere:

meanings.definition: to move your hand or an object onto the surface of something so that it touches it, usually with force:
examples: Teachers are not allowed to hit their pupils.

meanings.definition: to touch something with sudden force:

meanings.definition: to have an unpleasant or negative effect on a person or thing:

meanings.definition: If an idea or thought hits you, you suddenly think of it:

meanings.definition: to shoot at or bomb a place or person, causing damage or injury:

meanings.definition: to arrive at a place or position:

meanings.definition: to succeed in reaching or achieving something:
examples: Our profits hit an all-time high of $20 million last year.
I just can't hit (= sing) those high notes like I used to.

meanings.definition: to kill someone:

meanings.definition: in cricket, to score runs:

meanings.definition: in baseball, to hit the ball with a particular result :
examples: He hit a career-high 17 home runs last year.

meanings.definition: in baseball, to have a particular batting average (= a number that represents how often a player successfully hits the ball compared to the number of times they have a chance to hit the ball):

meanings.definition: a thing or person that is very popular or successful:

meanings.definition: a request to use a web page on the internet that is then counted to calculate the number of people looking at the page:
examples: Our page had 243 hits this week.

meanings.definition: the act of hitting something or someone, or an occasion when something or someone hits you:
examples: She gave him a hit on the head which knocked him flying.

meanings.definition: in baseball, when the batter (= person trying to hit the ball) safely reaches first base after hitting the ball
an occasion when something that has been thrown, dropped, shot, etc. at a place or object reaches that place or object:
examples: The rebel headquarters took a direct hit from a bomb during the attack.
I scored a hit on my second shot.

meanings.definition: an act of murder:
examples: He was the victim of a mafia hit.

meanings.definition: to touch quickly and forcefully, with the hand or an object:
examples: Don’t hit your little brother!

meanings.definition: If something hits part of your body, or you hit it, you come up against it by accident:
examples: He’s so tall he keeps hitting his head when he goes through a doorway.

meanings.definition: Someone who is hit by a bullet or explosive weapon is injured by it:
examples: One journalist was hit in the leg by a stray bullet.

meanings.definition: to have an unpleasant or negative effect on a person or thing:
examples: Commuters are going to be hit hard by the rise in gasoline prices.

meanings.definition: infml If an important fact hits you, you suddenly understand the meaning of it:
examples: It just hit me that once she leaves, I may never see her again.

meanings.definition: to arrive at a place, position, or state:
examples: The company’s profits hit an all-time high last year.

meanings.definition: to make a thrown baseball move within the playing area by touching it with a bat (= stick):
examples: Rodriguez hit a high fly ball that was caught by the shortstop.

meanings.definition: someone or something that is very popular or successful:
examples: The musical is one of the biggest hits on Broadway.

meanings.definition: a base hit:
examples: Jason had three hits in four times at bat.

meanings.definition: the act of hitting someone or something, or an occasion when someone or something is hit:
examples: The hospital took a direct hit from a bomb.

meanings.definition: to have an unpleasant or negative effect on someone or something :
examples: Rising fuel costs hit industrial and rural areas worst.

meanings.definition: to reach a particular level or amount, especially a very high or very low one:
examples: Sales hit $300 million within the first three years.

meanings.definition: to experience a difficult situation or stop making progress with something:

meanings.definition: a thing or person that is very popular or successful:

meanings.definition: a visit to a particular website on the internet, which is then counted to calculate the number of people who see the website:

meanings.definition: something that has an unpleasant or negative effect on a person or thing:
examples: Investors are worried about the direct hit to consumer confidence.

meanings.definition: to reach the normal or correct speed or state after starting slowly:
examples: The economic recovery hasn't hit full stride yet, but things look positive.

meanings.definition: a road accident in which the driver who caused the accident drives away without helping the other people involved and without telling the police:

meanings.definition: to attack or criticize someone who has attacked or criticized you:

meanings.definition: to attack or criticize someone who has attacked or criticized you:

meanings.definition: to cause you to realize exactly how unpleasant or difficult something is:

meanings.definition: to become completely understood:

meanings.definition: to be friendly with each other immediately:

meanings.definition: an activity that someone does for pleasure when they are not working:

meanings.definition: to drive so that other vehicles cannot go past
taking too much for yourself and only thinking about yourself

meanings.definition: to have a particular quality:

meanings.definition: to have a particular position in a competition:

meanings.definition: the act of holding something or someone, or the way you do this:

a place to put the hands and feet, especially when climbing
power or control over something or someone:

meanings.definition: to stop something from happening, or to delay something temporarily:

meanings.definition: If someone who committed a crime is held, that person is kept guarded in a police station.

meanings.definition: control or power over something or someone:

meanings.definition: the space in a ship or aircraft where goods are carried
(in some sports) a position in which one person prevents another from moving:

meanings.definition: to have something, especially a position or money, or to control something:

meanings.definition: to organize an event in which a group of people march or stand together to show that they disagree with or support something or someone:

meanings.definition: to be in a strong position when you are competing with someone else, because you have all the advantages:

meanings.definition: to not do something, often because of fear or because you do not want to make a bad situation worse:

meanings.definition: to stop someone or something developing or doing as well as they should:
examples: She felt that having children would hold her back.

meanings.definition: If you hold someone or something back, you stop him, her, or it from coming or moving forward:
examples: Sandbags will hold the flood waters back for a while.

meanings.definition: to keep information secret from someone deliberately
to stop yourself showing an emotion:
examples: He spoke slowly, to hold back his growing anger.

meanings.definition: to stop something from happening or advancing, or to keep someone from doing something:
examples: She held back from interfering in their arguments.

He admitted that something had gone wrong, but he held back the details (= stopped himself from telling the complete truth).

meanings.definition: to not speak or state an opinion:
examples: I held back during the meeting because I knew that my opinions were too controversial.

meanings.definition: to prevent someone or something from changing, moving, or developing:
examples: She hadn't got the promotion she wanted, and she accused her boss of holding her back.

meanings.definition: to wait for a period of time before doing something:
examples: We held back on the product release until the third quarter.

meanings.definition: to receive a lot of attention from other people who stand or sit around you to listen, especially on a social occasion:

meanings.definition: to manage to keep a job for a period of time
used to tell someone to stop what they are doing:
examples: Hold everything! He's changed his mind again.

meanings.definition: to talk about a particular subject for a long time, often in a way that other people find boring:
examples: She held forth all afternoon about/on government incompetence.

meanings.definition: to express your opinions for a long time:
examples: She held forth all through lunch on a variety of subjects.

meanings.definition: When two people hold hands, one person holds the other person's hand, especially to show that they love each other:
examples: They walked along holding hands.

meanings.definition: used to tell someone to wait or stop doing something:
examples: Hold it! I don't have my coat on yet.

meanings.definition: stop and do not continue what you are doing:

examples: He made a mistake but I don't hold it against him - we all make mistakes.

meanings.definition: to not do something immediately:
examples: Let's hold off making a decision until next week.

meanings.definition: If rain or a storm holds off, it does not start immediately.
to stop someone from attacking or defeating you:
examples: How much longer will the resistance fighters be able to hold off the enemy?

meanings.definition: to stop something from happening, or to be delayed:
examples: They’re hoping to hold off surgery until he’s stronger.

meanings.definition: to wait for a period of time before doing something:
examples: Holding off on the product release meant missing sales targets for the year.

meanings.definition: used to tell someone to wait for a short time:
examples: Hold on, I'll check in my diary.

meanings.definition: used to say that you are confused or surprised by something that you have just heard or read and want to understand it:
examples: Now hold on, Ed, that wasn't what we agreed at all!

meanings.definition: to manage to stay alive or to deal with a difficult situation:

meanings.definition: to hold something or someone firmly with your hands or arms:
examples: She held on tightly to his waist.

meanings.definition: to wait, esp. for someone to speak:
examples: She’s on the other line – can you hold on?

meanings.definition: to continue to do something difficult while waiting for help:

meanings.definition: to keep something or someone that is important or useful:
examples: I held onto the tech shares after the stock market fell because I knew they would recover.

meanings.definition: to continue doing something or staying somewhere although it is difficult or unpleasant to do so:
examples: Hold on and I’ll go and get some help.

meanings.definition: to hold something or someone firmly with your hands or your arms:
examples: Hold onto the rope and don't let go.

meanings.definition: to continue to keep something:
examples: Two local representatives held onto their seats in yesterday’s election.

meanings.definition: to keep something you have:
examples: Hold on to your ticket - you'll need it later.

meanings.definition: to continue to defend yourself against an enemy or attack without being defeated:
examples: They won't be able to hold out much longer under this sort of bombardment.

meanings.definition: If a supply of something such as food or money holds out, there is enough of it to last for a particular period of time.
to hold something in your hand with your arm stretched towards someone or something, especially when offering them something:
examples: Rosie held out an apple for the horse.
She held the letter out for me to read.

meanings.definition: to offer a possibility, solution, hope, etc.:
examples: Few people hold out any hope of finding more survivors.

meanings.definition: to continue in a situation that is dangerous or difficult:
examples: They won’t be able to hold out much longer against these attacks.

meanings.definition: If something holds out, it continues to be useful or enough:
examples: The sensors are designed to work as long as their batteries hold out.

meanings.definition: to offer or consider something as a possibility:
examples: Few people hold out any hope of finding more survivors.

meanings.definition: to wait until you get what you want:
examples: The workers are holding out for a ten percent pay rise.

meanings.definition: to continue to demand something, although you have been told you cannot have it:
examples: The workers are holding out for a pay increase.

meanings.definition: to not agree to something until you have got what you wanted:
examples: He held out for a bigger commission before signing the contract.

meanings.definition: to wait for something better:

meanings.definition: to refuse to give help or information to someone:
examples: Don't hold out on me - I need to know who did it.

meanings.definition: to refuse to give money to someone
to refuse to give help, information, or something of value to someone:
examples: Don’t hold out on me – I need to know who did it.

meanings.definition: to do or say something in order to show that you want to end a disagreement with someone:
examples: He held out an olive branch to the opposition by releasing 42 political prisoners.

meanings.definition: a suggestion that someone should not sell the shares that they own in a company, but that they should not buy any new shares:
examples: Despite falling sales, Citigroup is keeping its hold rating because the price of the stock is good compared with the rest of the sector.

meanings.definition: to make someone responsible for what they do and demand a satisfactory reason for it:
examples: It is important to hold schools accountable for the performance of all their students.
They want him to be held accountable for what he has done.

meanings.definition: to respect someone or have a good opinion of them:
examples: Because of their achievements they were held in esteem.
Be assured that I hold you in high esteem.

meanings.definition: to respect someone very much/very little:
examples: My father was held in high repute by his colleagues.

meanings.definition: to force someone to do something by putting that person in a situation where they have no choice:
examples: He claimed his country was being held ransom by threats of withdrawing aid.

meanings.definition: to make someone accept that they are responsible for something and explain their actions or decisions:
examples: Holding those in power to account is the essence of democracy.
Who can we hold to account for this most shameful episode in the nation's history?

meanings.definition: to force someone to do something by putting that person in a situation where they have no choice:
examples: He claimed his country was being held to ransom by threats of withdrawing aid.

meanings.definition: to make someone do what they promised or agreed to do:
examples: We'll hold him to the exact terms of the contract.

meanings.definition: to demand that someone act on a promise or agreement:
examples: They’re holding him to the exact terms of the contract.

meanings.definition: to keep someone or something in a particular place or position and to stop him, her, or it from moving:
examples: He was struggling so much it took three officers to hold him down.

meanings.definition: to keep something, especially costs, at a low level:
examples: to hold down prices/wages

meanings.definition: to stay working in a job:
examples: He’s never been able to hold down a steady job.

meanings.definition: to maintain something at a low level:
examples: Hold down the noise in there, kids!

meanings.definition: to keep something at a low level or to prevent it from rising:
examples: The Fed held down interest rates to encourage growth in the economy.

meanings.definition: to be able to keep a job:
examples: He couldn't hold down a job for more than a few months at a time.
She had three children, and still managed to hold down a full-time job.

meanings.definition: to feel contempt for someone or something:
examples: I would never hold someone in contempt for making a few mistakes in English.
I think history will hold us in contempt for what we are doing to the planet.
He had always held sport in contempt, preferring intellectual pursuits.
The party has now become tolerable to people who previously held it in contempt.
I hated spending time with them, as it was clear they held me in contempt.

meanings.definition: to laugh unkindly and publicly at someone or something, or to make someone or something seem stupid:
examples: Her plans were held up to ridicule.

meanings.definition: to consider something as a reason to have a bad opinion about someone or something:
examples: He made a mistake, but I don’t hold it against him – we all make mistakes.

meanings.definition: If someone holds something in abeyance, they stop it from happening or being used at present:
examples: The criminal charges are held in abeyance until the drug treatment programme is completed.
It seems wise to hold any such visit in abeyance.

meanings.definition: to delay something:
examples: The nomination was held over until the Senate adjourned.

meanings.definition: If a film, play, etc. is held over, it is shown or performed more times than was originally planned, usually because it is very popular with the public.
to delay someone from leaving:
examples: The weather held us over in Denver for two days.

meanings.definition: to delay something, or delay someone from leaving:
examples: The nomination was held over until the Senate adjourned, allowing a recess appointment.
The weather held us over in Denver for two days.

meanings.definition: to not deal with something now, but wait to deal with it later:
examples: Strike negotiations were held over until the new year.
We'll have to hold these last agenda items over till the next meeting.

meanings.definition: to use someone or something as an example of something, especially something very good:
examples: Sweden is often held up as an example of a successful social democracy.

meanings.definition: used to tell someone to stop moving:
examples: Hold still, this won't hurt.

meanings.definition: to have power or a very strong influence:
examples: Fundamentalist beliefs hold sway over whole districts, ensuring the popularity of religious leaders.

meanings.definition: used for telling someone to remember an idea or thought that has just been mentioned, especially because it will be useful later
to be able to support either opposing side in a competition, etc. and therefore be able to decide who will win:
examples: If independents do end up holding the balance of power, then they decide whether Labor or the Liberals govern for the next four years.

meanings.definition: to speak to a group of people, often for a long time, without allowing anyone else to speak
to have responsibility for something while someone else is absent:
examples: I’m leaving my husband to hold the fort while I’m away.

meanings.definition: to have control of something:
examples: Because the two main parties have won almost the same number of votes, the minority group holds the key to the result.

meanings.definition: used for telling someone to wait, for example because you are going to say something surprising; sometimes used humorously when something is not surprising at all:
examples: It may sound like a great offer, but hold the phone.
It's amazing to actually find a steak that's been cooked well and, hold the phone, well seasoned!
Hold the phone, commentators are claiming he's a weaker rugby player than he was before his injury. Well, you don't say.

meanings.definition: be in control:
examples: She's the boss but her secretary often seems to hold the reins.

meanings.definition: If a vehicle holds the road, its wheels stay firmly on the road and do not slide while moving.
to keep (a group or organization) complete or in its original state or condition:
examples: Social relationships held the Crow people together into the 20th century.

meanings.definition: to continue to be true:

meanings.definition: to remain strong or successful:

meanings.definition: to delay someone or something:
examples: Traffic was held up for several hours by the accident.

meanings.definition: to steal from someone using violence or the threat of violence:
examples: They held the same bank up twice in one week.

meanings.definition: to raise your hand or something that you are holding in your hand:
examples: All those who agree, please hold up your hand.

meanings.definition: If a centre forward holds up the ball, they keep control of a long pass from a defender on the same team until other members of the team can reach the opponent's half of the playing field:
examples: Lukaku used his strength to hold up the ball, giving Baines time to sprint downfield in support.

meanings.definition: a delay:
examples: Come on, let's go. What's the hold-up?

meanings.definition: an occasion when someone steals from someone else using violence or the threat of violence:
examples: In the hold-up, a masked youth threatened the bank staff with a gun.

meanings.definition: to continue to operate or be able to do things, esp. after being repaired or being ill:
examples: I hope the spare tire holds up until we can get to a garage.

meanings.definition: If information holds up, it is proved to be true:
examples: The evidence may not hold up in court.

meanings.definition: to delay someone or something:
examples: Traffic was held up for several hours by the accident.

meanings.definition: to try to steal money or property from a person, a bank, or a business by using violence or threats:
examples: They held up the same store twice.

meanings.definition: to offer something or someone as an example:
examples: Her parents always held her sister up to her as the kind of person she should be.

meanings.definition: to stay strong or well:
examples: The real estate market held up despite a lack of consumer confidence.

meanings.definition: to not do something immediately:
examples: They held up releasing specifications until the patents were granted.

meanings.definition: to stop something getting somewhere, or making progress:
examples: The documents were held up in the post, so the sale was delayed.

meanings.definition: a delay that prevents something from happening:

meanings.definition: If a reason, argument, or explanation holds water, it is true:
examples: Her alibi just didn't hold water.

meanings.definition: to seem to be true or reasonable:
examples: The jury convicted her because her story just didn’t hold water.

meanings.definition: to keep air in your lungs and not release it so that you need more:
examples: How long can you hold your breath under water?

meanings.definition: to wait for something to happen, often feeling anxious:

meanings.definition: to be very confident and proud:

meanings.definition: used to tell someone to stop and consider carefully their decision or opinion about something:

meanings.definition: to be as successful as other people or things in a situation: to not become more ill or more weak:

a word that is spelled the same as another word but has a different meaning and may have a different pronunciation:
examples: "Bow" meaning the front of a ship, "bow" meaning a loop made in a string or ribbon, and "bow" meaning a device used to shoot arrows are all homographs.
Normally the meaning of a homograph is established by its context.

meanings.definition: a word which is spelled the same as another word, but that has a different meaning, origin, or pronunciation
(of words) having the same spelling but different meanings; related to words like this:
examples: In reading, the children made more errors on words with homographic spelling patterns than on other words.

meanings.definition: the fact of words having the same spelling but different meanings:
examples: Homography is very common in both Arabic and Hebrew.

meanings.definition: to show that two things have a similar position, structure, origin, or purpose:
examples: From the fossil remains, we can recognize two forearm bones as well as other elements that we can homologize with the wrist bones of tetrapods.
Buildings may be homologised to natural structures, and conversely, natural structures may be described in architectural terms.

meanings.definition: having a similar position, structure, value, or purpose:
examples: These activities are meant to be homologous to modern work conditions.
A model represents, or is homologous with, a specific aspect of perceived reality.

meanings.definition: having the same origin although now having a different purpose or shape, usually as a result of evolution (= gradual change over millions of years):
examples: The wing of a bat and the arm of a man are homologous structures.
A female's paraurethral glands are homologous to the male prostate.
Feathers are traditionally considered homologous with reptilian scales.

meanings.definition: (of a chromosome) containing similar information to another chromosome that it forms a pair with during meiosis (= a type of cell division):
examples: In this case a pair of homologous chromosomes fail to separate from one another during meiosis.

meanings.definition: similar in position, structure, or purpose

two chromosomes (= cell parts that control what an animal or plant is like), one from the father and one from the mother, that come together during meiosis (= cell division that happens as part of reproduction)
a series of organic substances (= substances containing the element carbon) with similar characteristics
a series of organic substances (= substances containing the element carbon) with similar characteristics
something that has a similar position, structure, value, or purpose to something else:

meanings.definition: something that has the same origin as something else but now has a different purpose or shape as a result of evolution (= gradual change over millions of years):

meanings.definition: a chromosome (= a rod-like structure in cells, containing the chemical patterns that control what an animal or plant is like) that contains similar information to another chromosome that it forms a pair with during meiosis (= a type of cell division) :

meanings.definition: a word that sounds the same or is spelled the same as another word but has a different meaning:

meanings.definition: a word that has the same spelling and pronunciation as another word but a different meaning:

meanings.definition: a word that is spelled the same as another word but that does not have the same meaning:

meanings.definition: A homonym is also a homophone.

meanings.definition: the fact of words having the same spelling or pronunciation or both, but different meanings:

meanings.definition: policies, behaviours, rules, etc. that result in a continued unfair advantage to straight people (= men who are attracted to women and women who are attracted to men) and unfair or harmful treatment of gay people or queer people (= people who do not fit a society’s traditional ideas about gender or sexuality):

examples: The homophobic environment in the office made it impossible to retain gay employees.

meanings.definition: a word which is pronounced the same as another word, but which has a different meaning or spelling:

meanings.definition: consisting of only one tune or part that is played or sung, or several parts that are played or sung in harmony (= with different notes being played or sung at the same time) with the main melody, and often also in the same rhythm, or relating to or producing such a sound:

meanings.definition: (of words) pronounced the same, but having a different meaning, or a different spelling and meaning:

an exclamation used to express approval, agreement or encouragement, especially by Navy SEALs (= members of a highly trained force within the navy in the US and some other countries that deals with special operations involving water):
examples: If you follow this Guide to Navy SEAL fitness, you'll be in great shape in 12 weeks. Hooyah!

meanings.definition: to jump on one foot or to move about in this way:

meanings.definition: to go somewhere quickly or to get into or out of a vehicle quickly:
examples: We hopped over to Bruges for the weekend.

meanings.definition: If a small animal, bird, or insect hops, it moves by jumping on all or two of its feet at the same time:
examples: The rabbit/bird hopped across the grass.

meanings.definition: a short jump by a person on one foot, or by a small animal, bird, or insect on all or two of its feet at the same time:

examples: a hop plant

meanings.definition: used to tell someone to go away
to want something to happen or to be true, and usually have a good reason to think that it might:
examples: I'm hoping for an interview next week.
She's hoping (that) she won't be away too long.
I hope (that) she'll win.
We have to hope and pray (that) the operation will go well.
They hope to visit us next year.
It's good news, I hope.
"Will you be at the meeting tomorrow?" "I hope not/so".

meanings.definition: something good that you want to happen in the future, or a confident feeling about what will happen in the future:
examples: What are your hopes and dreams for the future?
Is there any hope of getting financial support for the project?
Is there any hope that they will be home in time?
Young people are growing up in our cities without any hope of finding a job.
His reply dashed (= destroyed) our hopes.
They have pinned (all) their hopes on (= they are depending for success on) their new player.
She's very ill, but there's still hope/we live in hope (= we think she might be cured).
The situation is now beyond/past hope (= unlikely to produce the desired result).
We never gave up hope (= stopped hoping) that she would be found alive.
The letter offered us a glimmer/ray of (= a little) hope.
I didn't phone until four o'clock in the hope that you'd be finished.
I don't hold out much hope of getting (= I don't expect to be able to get) a ticket.

meanings.definition: the feeling that something desired can be had or will happen:
examples: We never entirely gave up hope.
This research offers hope of developing better ways to treat cancer.
He had hopes of being chosen for the leading part in the play.

meanings.definition: to express the feeling or wish that something desired will happen:
examples: I’m hoping the company gives us a bonus this year.
We hope to see you soon.
I hope (that) his plane won’t be delayed.

meanings.definition: to hope very strongly that something will happen, although you know it is not likely:
examples: They're just hoping against hope that she's still alive.

meanings.definition: clothes, sheets, etc. that a young woman traditionally collects for use after she is married:
examples: Kate's grandmother gave her a quilt for her hope chest.

meanings.definition: to hope that something will be successful or happen in the way you want, even if it seems unlikely:
examples: I've repaired it as well as I can - we'll just have to hope for the best.

meanings.definition: said in order to express the idea that someone hopes that something will work well in the future, although experience shows that it has not worked well in the past:
examples: Hasty company mergers are often a triumph of hope over experience.
Oscar Wilde described second marriages as the triumph of hope over experience.
Despite multiple divorces and a string of failed romances, he somehow encapsulates the spirit of hope over experience.

meanings.definition: said when you continue to hope that something will happen, although it seems unlikely
used for emphasis:
examples: I hope to God (that) he turns up.
I swear to God (that) I didn't know about it.

meanings.definition: a person who wants to achieve a position of power:

meanings.definition: used, often at the start of a sentence, to express what you would like to happen:

meanings.definition: the feeling or state of having hope:

meanings.definition: without hope:

meanings.definition: completely without skill at a particular activity:
examples: I'm hopeless at sports.

meanings.definition: without hope:

meanings.definition: extremely, or in a way that makes you lose hope:

meanings.definition: the quality of being without skill at a particular activity:

a high-income/low-income/middle-income household
I sometimes wonder how my wife and I manage as a single-income household.
High-technology products are hard to sell to households where the head of the household is over 60 years of age.

meanings.definition: relating to a house or flat and the people who live there:
examples: Public housing tenants are required to pay 30 per cent of their household income for rent.
It's no surprise that household debt is rising.
The average annual household expenditure for food was $2,030.

meanings.definition: used to describe something that is used in the home:
examples: a household appliance/item/product
Over the last two decades, household water consumption per head in London has increased by 22%.

meanings.definition: equipment, tools, machines, and other things used in a house:
examples: All our household goods are insured against accidental damage.

meanings.definition: equipment, tools, and machines used in the home:
examples: The site allows shoppers to compare the price of household goods from alarm clocks to kettles.

meanings.definition: insurance against damage to a building and the things it contains:
examples: Anyone buying a property without household insurance is unlikely to get a mortgage.

meanings.definition: a famous person that most people know of:
examples: He was a household name in the 1950s.

meanings.definition: the name or brand of a product that is very well known:
examples: The vacuum cleaner is the leading brand in the market and a household name.

meanings.definition: an insurance policy against damage to a building and the things it contains:
examples: Find out whether your household policy covers garden furniture.

meanings.definition: a cleaning product used in the home:
examples: Some brands say that their bottles of cleansers and other household products are attractive enough to be put on display.

meanings.definition: a word or name that everyone knows:
examples: McDonalds quickly became a household word.

meanings.definition: the person who owns or is in charge of a house
the person who owns or is in charge of a house:
examples: Householders need to take out home contents and buildings insurance.

meanings.definition: a person, especially a woman, whose job is to organize another person's house and deal with cooking, cleaning, etc.
a person, usually a woman, whose job is to take care of another person’s house, esp. by cleaning it
the management of a home and the work that needs to be done in it, such as cleaning :
examples: She had a relaxed attitude to housekeeping.

meanings.definition: the department of a hotel that is responsible for cleaning guest's bedrooms:
examples: the Ritz-Carlton's head of housekeeping

meanings.definition: the money used for buying food and other things necessary for living in a house:
examples: My grandfather used to give my grandmother housekeeping each week.

meanings.definition: used to refer to tasks that need to be done as a regular part of your work but are not the main purpose of your work:
examples: The teachers' meeting deals mostly with housekeeping issues such as lunchtime supervision duties.

meanings.definition: the activity of taking care of a house, esp. by cleaning it:
examples: She does some light housekeeping for us.

meanings.definition: the work involved in looking after a house or a hotel, for example the cleaning:
examples: The owners were forced to handle the housekeeping, cooking, and day-to-day operations themselves.

meanings.definition: jobs that are done regularly to keep a computer or office system working effectively:
examples: Basic computer housekeeping tips include instructions on how to correctly shut down your machine.

meanings.definition: money used for buying food and other things necessary for living in a house:
examples: a housekeeping allowance

meanings.definition: any of several different wild and garden plants with succulent leaves (= thick ones that can store a lot of water) that grow in round, flat shapes :
examples: Houseleeks grow in fleshy-leaved rosettes and do particularly well in containers.
The cobweb houseleeks are covered in soft, silvery hairs.

meanings.definition: a woman servant whose job is to clean a large house, and who often lives there
a painful knee usually caused by being on the knees too much
a male or female doctor working in a hospital who is in their first year after completing their medical degree:
examples: He persuaded a fellow houseman to examine him and pronounce him cured.
She was a qualified doctor working as a houseman in a hospital pathology department.

meanings.definition: a male teacher who is in charge of the children who live in one of several separate buildings in a school
someone you live with in a house but are not related to and do not have a romantic or sexual relationship with
a female teacher who is in charge of the children who live in one of several separate buildings in a school
a plant that is grown in a container inside a house
very worried about your house being completely clean and tidy, and spending a lot of time making it so
to consider or allow something or someone as a possibility:
examples: I don't know why they give houseroom to such idiotic complaints.
The government needs its collective head examined for even giving the idea house-room.

meanings.definition: equipment, tools, and machines used in a house, especially in the kitchen:
examples: the housewares department of a supermarket

meanings.definition: equipment esp. for the kitchen that is sold in a store

→ 
        
         household goods  :
examples: We offer a wide range of clothing, furniture and linen, housewares and garden essentials.

meanings.definition: a party that you give when you move into a new house:
examples: We're having a housewarming on Friday if you'd like to come.

meanings.definition: a party that you give when you move into a new home
a woman whose work is inside the home, doing the cleaning, cooking, etc., and who usually does not have any other job
someone who manages a home and family instead of earning money from employment
like or typical of a housewife (= a woman whose work is inside the home, doing the cleaning, cooking, etc.):
examples: She had taken on the role of housewifely caretaker.
At four o'clock every day she did a housewifely tidying up.

meanings.definition:
plural of 
        
         housewife
the work of keeping a house clean and tidy:
examples: I hate doing housework.

meanings.definition: the work that you do around a house, for example cleaning, cooking, and washing clothes
buildings for people to live in:
examples: There's a shortage of cheap housing in the region.

meanings.definition: a case or covering that surrounds a machine or part of a machine:
examples: The engine appeared to be intact except for the loss of its housing.
The underwater cable housings must be able to resist corrosion from salt water.

meanings.definition: buildings that people live in, or the providing of places for people to live:
examples: affordable/expensive housing

meanings.definition: buildings for people to live in, used especially when talking about their price or condition:
examples: There was a need to provide housing for workers in the new industries.
55% of respondents live in rented housing and 30% are owner-occupiers.
Lack of access to affordable housing is a problem for young people in the area.

meanings.definition: the process of providing places for people to live:
examples: The post will suit someone who is currently working in housing or urban planning.
a housing committee/department/officer

meanings.definition: a hard cover used to protect a vehicle or machine:
examples: The rotary engine housing prevents scuffing.

meanings.definition: a group of people who join together so that they can build or buy houses or apartments at low cost
in the UK, an organization that provides houses or apartments for people to rent at low cost:
examples: 65% of the housing stock here is owner occupied, with 24% rented from the local authority or a housing association.

meanings.definition: in the UK, money paid by the government to help people who are poor pay for a place to live in
in the UK, money paid by the government to help people who are on a low income pay for a place to live in:
examples: Regulations place a duty on local authorities to ensure housing benefit is processed and paid in two weeks.

meanings.definition: a time when the price of houses rises quickly:
examples: The main reason for the housing boom was a massive imbalance between supply and demand: too much money chasing too few properties.

meanings.definition: in the UK, houses or apartments owned by a group of people who rent them to others at a low cost:
examples: Living in a housing co-operative can be a good way to get affordable housing and may give you more control over where you live.

meanings.definition: an area containing a large number of houses or apartments built close together at the same time:
examples: Without this money a much-needed housing development in one of the poorest areas of London cannot go ahead.

meanings.definition: an area containing a large number of houses or apartments built close together at the same time:
examples: They live on/in a housing estate.

meanings.definition: a group of houses built together in a planned way, sometimes by the local government of an area in order to provide houses for people to rent or buy at a low cost:
examples: The Prime Minister visited a London housing estate to publicize the police's new powers to tackle anti-social behaviour.

meanings.definition: the type, cost, and number of houses and apartments available in a particular area:
examples: The suburbs of New York City are the most overvalued housing market in the country.

meanings.definition: the activity of buying and selling houses, etc.:
examples: The housing market has failed to pick up in the past two months.

meanings.definition: a group of houses or apartments, usually provided by the government for families who have low incomes
a group of houses or apartments, usually provided by the government for families who have very low incomes
the number of new houses, apartments, etc. on which building work has started within a particular time, used as a measure of economic growth:
examples: He predicted the Chicago region's housing starts to be down 24 per cent from the previous year.

meanings.definition: the houses and other places to live that are available in a town, country, area, etc.:
examples: The Chancellor has pledged to increase the housing stock.
About 12% of the city's housing stock falls into the category of affordable homes.

meanings.definition: the largest city in the southern US state of Texas:
examples: She travelled back from Houston.
Houston is an international city.

meanings.definition: someone from the US city of Houston:
examples: It's so nice to meet another Houstonian!
The restaurant was popular among young Houstonians.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for high-occupancy vehicle: a road vehicle that carries a lot of people such as a bus, or a car with a driver and one or more passenngers:
examples: Solo drivers can pay to ride on the HOV lanes.
In the morning and afternoon rush hours HOV restrictions are enforced.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for high-occupancy vehicle lane: a lane (= a section ) on a wide road that is only to be used by a vehicle that carries a lot of people such as a bus, or by a car with a driver and one or more passengers, or sometimes by other vehicles that must pay a charge:
examples: Solo drivers in Houston will pay a steep price to ride in the HOV lanes.
The freeway will be expanded to four lanes each side, plus HOV lanes.

meanings.definition: a small home that is dirty and in bad condition
a small home, esp. one that is dirty and in bad condition:
examples: Their house was little more than a hovel.

meanings.definition: to stay in one place in the air, usually by moving the wings quickly:
examples: A hawk hovered in the sky, waiting to swoop down on its prey.
I heard the noise of a helicopter hovering overhead.

meanings.definition: to stand somewhere, especially near another person, eagerly or nervously waiting for their attention:
examples: A waiter hovered at the table, ready to take our order.
I could sense him behind me, hovering and building up the courage to ask me a question.

meanings.definition: to stay at or near a particular level:
examples: Inflation is hovering at three percent.

meanings.definition: to put the cursor on a computer screen in a particular place without clicking on it:
examples: The link changes to green when the mouse hovers over it.
If you hover the mouse pointer over the entry, the full web address will be displayed.

meanings.definition: to stay in the air in one place:
examples: A helicopter hovered overhead.

meanings.definition: A person who hovers stands near someone, waiting for attention:
examples: She hovered outside her boss’s door.

meanings.definition: a lawnmower that cuts grass with blades that spin round, and that is held slightly above the ground by a current of air below it
a brand name for a form of transport for one person, consisting of a small board on which the person balances, with two wheels and a motor:
examples: It's illegal to ride hoverboards on streets and sidewalks in some countries.

meanings.definition: a form of transport existing only in films and stories, that a person can stand on and that floats a short distance above the ground:
examples: How is it that several decades after Back To The Future Part II came out, we're still waiting for our hoverboards?

meanings.definition: a vehicle that travels quickly just above the surface of water or land by producing a current of air under it to support it

meanings.definition: a place where people get on or off a hovercraft
in what way, or by what methods:
examples: How do we get to the town from here?
How did you hear about the concert?
How does this machine work?
How do you plan to spend your holiday?
Roz doesn't know how to ride a bicycle.
It all depends on how you look at it.
I don't care about fashion, I dress how I please.
I was horrified to hear about how (= the way) she had been treated.
How can/could he be so stupid?
I don't know how anyone could think that way.

meanings.definition: used to ask about someone's physical or emotional state:
examples: How is your mother?
How are you feeling this morning?

meanings.definition: used in questions that ask what an experience or event was like:
examples: How was your flight?
How did you find the lecture? (= did you think it was good)?
How did you like the concert (= did you enjoy it)?
She didn't say how far it is (= what the distance is) to her house.
How long are you going to be (= what amount of time are you going to spend) in the bathroom?
Do you know how many (= what number of) people are coming?
How much does this cost (= what is its price)?
How old is his daughter (= what age is she)?
"Can you lift this case?" "It depends on how heavy it is."
Do you remember how (= the fact that) we used to see every new film as soon as it came out?

meanings.definition: used for emphasis:
examples: I can't tell you how pleased I am (= I am very pleased) that you came.
How (= it is very) nice to see you!
"She paid for everything." "How (= that was very) generous."

meanings.definition: in what way or state, to what amount or degree, or for what reason:
examples: How do we get to the interstate highway from here?
How did you hear about the concert?
How is your mother?
How did you like the movie?
How much does this cost?
How old is his daughter?
She didn’t say how far it is to her house.
How long are you going to be at the gym?

meanings.definition: How is sometimes used for emphasis:
examples: How nice to see you!

meanings.definition: the way or condition in which:
examples: Do you know how this machine works?
Roz doesn’t know how to ride a bicycle.
I was horrified to hear about how she had been treated.

meanings.definition: used to emphasize that something is surprising:
examples: Sales are up by 36 percent. How about that?

meanings.definition: used to make a suggestion: used when asking someone about a different thing:
examples: How about the cinema tonight?
How about going to the cinema?
You don't eat meat, do you? How about fish?

meanings.definition: infml I suggest this:
examples: How about going out for a walk after dinner?

meanings.definition: informal for "how are you?"
used as greetings:
examples: I haven't seen you for ages, Carol. How are things?
Nice to see you, Will. How's everything?
How's it going, Ruby? Have you found a job yet?
Hello, Rupert. How are things?
I didn't know you'd be here, Lucy. How's it going?

how-are-you-fixed-for.name: how are you fixed for something?

meanings.definition: used to ask how much of something someone has, or to ask about someone's arrangements:
examples: How are you fixed for cash?
How are you fixed for Saturday evening?

meanings.definition: used to ask if someone is well:
examples: How's your mother keeping?

meanings.definition: used to ask someone if they have enough money, time, etc.:
examples: How are you placed for money?
How are you placed for Tuesday night? (= Are you busy then?)

meanings.definition: used to ask someone if they are well and happy:
examples: "Hi, Lucy, how are you?" "Fine, thanks, how are you?"
How are you now that you've settled into your new home?
She looked at Paul anxiously and asked, "How are you?"
Cathy said she thought you were fine, but how are you really?
Hello, Mrs Evans. How are you today?

meanings.definition: used to ask about the reason for something:
examples: So how come you got an invitation and not me?
"I don't think I'll be able to go swimming tomorrow." "How come?"

meanings.definition: infml why did something happen:
examples: How come you got invited and I didn’t?

meanings.definition: used to express anger about something someone has done:
examples: How dare you use my car without asking!
How dare he tell me what to do!

meanings.definition: I am very surprised and shocked by what you are doing:
examples: How dare you question my authority?

meanings.definition: a formal greeting for someone that you have not met before:
examples: "I'm Jack Stewart." "How do you do? I'm Angela Black."

meanings.definition: a difficult, worrying, and unpleasant situation:
examples: "I had a row with my sister and now she's refusing to talk to me." "Well, that's a fine how do you do!"

meanings.definition: used when asking someone how they like their drinks made: used when asking someone for an opinion:
examples: "How do you like your tea?" "Milk and one sugar, please."
How do you like my new shoes?

meanings.definition: used when you want someone to explain what they have just said:
examples: "I think we need to reconsider our position." "How do you mean?"
You think he's a threat? How do you mean?
"I always thought she was odd." "Odd? How do you mean?"
I know you think we're irresponsible, but how do you mean exactly?
"How do you want this information to be used?" "How do you mean, be used?"

meanings.definition: used to ask if someone would like to do something or is interested in something:
examples: We could have a picnic in the park. How does that grab you?

how-long-is-a-piece-of-string.name: how long is a piece of string?

meanings.definition: said when you cannot answer a question about the length, size, amount, etc. of something because it could be any length, size, etc.:
examples: Asked how long this will take, she replies: "How long is a piece of string?"
And the cost? How long is a piece of string?

how-much-do-you-want-to-bet.name: (how much) do you want to bet?

meanings.definition: said in answer to something that someone has said, meaning that you are certain that they are wrong:
examples: "Surely she won't be late this time." "How much do you want to bet?"

meanings.definition: how someone generally likes to do things:
examples: Not a good system you say, but that's how I roll.
I know people who lease a new car every year. That's how they roll.

meanings.definition: I cannot be expected to know:
examples: "Where's Mikey?" "How should I know? He's hardly ever in the office these days."

how-strange-stupid-weird-etc-is-that.name: how strange, stupid, weird, etc. is that?

meanings.definition: used to emphasize that something is strange, stupid, etc.:
examples: She let me go on the yacht. How cool is that?
He wants to watch a documentary about whales. How boring is that?
Louise has got us all tickets for the show. How great is that?
My dad became a mushroom farmer. How weird is that?
I forgot to buy milk, even though that's the whole reason I went to the store in the first place. How stupid is that?

meanings.definition: something people say when they see or hear about the lives of people who are richer than them
used to say that something you did wrong was not your fault because you did not have enough information:
examples: I just wanted to give her a surprise; how was I to know you'd already bought tickets?

meanings.definition: said to suggest that someone would not like to be in a situation experienced by someone else:
examples: I'm not surprised he shouted at you! How would you like to be pushed into a wall?

meanings.definition: said as an informal greeting
used when asking if something you have done for someone is satisfactory:
examples: Let me put a cushion behind your back. How's that?
"Could you close the window slightly?" "Sure. How's that?"
I can give you another blanket. How's that?
"Would you turn the music up a bit, please?" "Sure. How's that?"
"The water's a bit too hot." "OK, how's that? Is it better?"

meanings.definition: how are you?:
examples: "Hi, how's tricks?" "Oh, fine, how are you doing?"

meanings.definition: an informal way to greet someone you know and ask how they are:
examples: How's you? How was work today?

how-what-why-etc-on-earth.name: how, what, why, etc. on earth...

meanings.definition: used when you are extremely surprised, confused, or angry about something:
examples: How on earth did this happen?
Why on earth didn't you tell me before?

meanings.definition: A how-to book, video, or other product provides advice on how to do a particular thing:
examples: How-to books on dieting are often at the top of the bestseller lists.
There have been few how-to guides about making a career writing your own music.

meanings.definition: a book, video, or other product that provides advice on a particular activity:
examples: It reads like a how-to for any business person.
He contacted mountaineer Gerry Roach, author of a popular how-to on the subject.

meanings.definition: a piece of advice about a particular activity:
examples: We've picked out our favourite clothes pieces this season, with how-tos on working them into your wardrobe.
He has even laid out all the how-tos on his website.

meanings.definition: used to describe something that provides practical advice on a particular activity:
examples: a how-to book/guide/article

meanings.definition: a book, DVD, etc. that gives practical advice on a particular activity:
examples: I have a shelf full of how-tos, but I'm an expert on nothing.

meanings.definition: used when suggesting or offering something to someone:
examples: How about a trip to the zoo this afternoon?
"Coffee, Sarah?" "No, thanks." "What about you, Kate?"

meanings.definition: hello
used as a greeting; hello:
examples: Howdy, folks! When did you all get here?

meanings.definition: despite whatever amount or degree:
examples: However hungry I am, I never seem to be able to finish off a whole pizza.
If Emma likes something she'll buy it however much it costs.
I'll see you after the show and give you £20 for the tickets, or however much (= whatever) they cost.

meanings.definition: used to express surprise:
examples: However did you manage to get him to agree to that?

meanings.definition: in whatever way:
examples: However you look at it, it's still a mess.
You can do it however you like, it really doesn't matter.

meanings.definition: despite this:
examples: This is one possible solution to the problem. However, there are others.
There may, however, be other reasons that we don't know about.

meanings.definition: to whatever amount or degree:
examples: However fast we drive, we’re not going to get there in time.
If Emma likes something she’ll buy it, however much it costs.

meanings.definition: in whatever way:
examples: However you look at it, it’s still a mess.

meanings.definition: despite this; nevertheless:
examples: There may, however, be other reasons that we don’t know about.

meanings.definition: in whatever way:
examples: You can do it however you like, it really doesn’t matter.

meanings.definition: a large gun which fires shells (= very large bullets) high into the air so that they drop onto the place at which they are aimed
If a dog or wolf howls, it makes a long, sad sound:
examples: In the silence of the night, a lone wolf howled.

meanings.definition: to make a loud sound, usually to express pain, sadness, or another strong emotion:
examples: An injured dog lay in the middle of the road, howling with/in pain.
We were howling with laughter.
The opposition howled down the government's proposal (= shouted loudly to express disapproval).

meanings.definition: If the wind howls, it blows hard and makes a lot of noise:
examples: Is there someone outside, or is it just the wind howling in the trees?

meanings.definition: a long, loud, sad sound:
examples: the howl of the wind in the trees
He leaves his dog shut up in the house all day, and we can hear its howls.
She let out a howl of pain.

meanings.definition: a strong expression of emotion, such as anger or disagreement:
examples: Plans to build a new supermarket have been greeted with howls of protest from local residents.

meanings.definition: to make a long, high, crying sound, like that of a dog:
examples: Toby stepped on a nail, and he howled in pain.
The wind howled.
fig. The senators kept howling (= loudly complaining) that there was not enough money in the budget to pay for the president’s plan.

meanings.definition: a long, high, crying sound:
examples: the howl of the wind
fig. The loudest howl (= strongly expressed complaint) seemed to come from farmers in the Midwest.

examples: In the silence of the night, a lone wolf howled.
