meanings.definition: If the wind howls, it blows hard and makes a lot of noise:
examples: Is there someone outside, or is it just the wind howling in the trees?

meanings.definition: a stupid and obvious mistake, especially in something that someone says or writes:
examples: I called her by the name of his first wife, which was a bit of a howler.
So far in the election, no candidate has committed a shocking howler.

meanings.definition: a jug or large bottle that can be filled with beer, especially at a brewery (= a place where beer is made). A howler usually contains 32 fluid ounces:
examples: Howlers are perfect if you're looking to bring home multiple draft beers but don't want a full growler of each.

meanings.definition: (of the wind) blowing hard and making a lot of noise:
examples: Once we played crazy golf in a howling gale.
The hurricane's howling destructive winds just missed the island.

meanings.definition: (of a dog or wolf) making a loud, sad sound:
examples: Their howling dogs keep us awake at night.
They did their best to ignore the howling wolves.

meanings.definition: (of people) making a lot of noise:
examples: Their premises were stormed by a howling drunken mob.

meanings.definition: used to emphasize that something is very good or bad:
examples: Neither film was a howling success.
This is yet another howling example of British hypocrisy.
It is a howling omission, Mr Brown.

meanings.definition: the sound of a wind blowing hard and making a lot of noise:
examples: No sound remained but the howling of the wind.

meanings.definition: the sound of dogs or wolves making a loud, sad sound:
examples: Nearby she heard the howling of the wolves.

meanings.definition: If someone or something is howlingly funny or howlingly bad, for example, they are very funny or very bad:
examples: This smart film is howlingly funny.
Her novels are deeply funny and howlingly sad, as only novels about real things can be.

meanings.definition:
formal for
        
         however
in cricket, the word that a player calls out when they think the batter (= the player trying to hit the ball) is out (= can no longer continue playing):
examples: The bowler yelled "howzat" with arms extended but the umpire just shook his head.
Unless you appeal by saying "howzat", the umpire can't give someone out.

meanings.definition: hello
a climbing Asian and Australian evergreen (= that never loses its leaves) tropical plant with white and pink flowers, grown in gardens or in a container inside a house:
examples: The hoya now spread its vines down to the floor and across the walls.
Hoyas come in different shapes and sizes and have the daintiest of blooms with a lovely smell.

written abbreviation for
        
         horsepower

abbreviation for
        
         hire purchase UK :
examples: We bought our television on HP.

abbreviation for

abbreviation for House Price Index: a series of figures showing the average price of houses and apartments in a particular country or area:
examples: The building society's HPI shows falls in house prices of an average of 2% over the last three months.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for human papilloma virus: a large group of viruses, some of which can cause warts (= small hard lumps) in the genital areas:
examples: HPV causes anogenital warts, one of the most common sexually acquired infections.

examples: We've just received instructions from HQ.

examples: He ran the marathon in 2 hrs 48 mins.
The plane departs at 15.00 hrs.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for human resources:
examples: An ageing workforce is a worry to many HR bosses.
I work in HR and see a lot of job applications from people with no experience.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for hour

abbreviation for 
        
         human resources   or 
        
         human resource management  :
examples: I know from having worked in HR for many years that employers rate this qualification highly.
We have developed a checklist of questions that HR managers could use in interviews.

meanings.definition: the process of combining all the systems to do with managing human resources (= people) in a business so that they work effectively together for the best results:
examples: I was on the global HR integration team of my previous company.

         human resource planning
written abbreviation for hours: used when giving times or saying how long something will take:
examples: Opening times are 0900-2300 hrs.
Orders will usually be shipped within 48 hrs.

meanings.definition:
abbreviation for
        
         hormone replacement therapy  : a treatment for women whose levels of female hormones are low because they have reached the menopause (= the time in a woman’s life when blood stops flowing from her uterus permanently):
examples: Doctors advise women who are interested in HRT to begin taking hormones early in the menopause so they can receive the maximum benefits of the treatment.

meanings.definition:
abbreviation for
        
         hormone replacement therapy  : a medical treatment given to transgender people (= people whose gender does not match the body they were born with) to help their body develop some physical characteristics that match their gender identity :
examples: As part of their transition, they began HRT.

abbreviation for

abbreviation for Health and Safety Authority: in some countries, the government organization that deals with preventing industrial accidents or finding out what caused them, the health of workers, etc.:

abbreviation for High School Equivalency Diploma: an official document in the US that is given to someone who did not complete high school (= school for students aged 15 to 18) but who has passed an exam of a similar standard as well as completing some other work:
examples: The HSED is a good option for students who haven't had the chance to earn a traditional high school diploma.

meanings.definition:
written abbreviation for
        
         height  :

meanings.definition: written abbreviation for hope this helps: used, in an email for example, when you send someone information that you think is useful, often when answering a question

abbreviation for hypertext markup language (= a system for representing documents on computers)

an HTML file/document

abbreviation for 
        
         Harmonized Tariff Schedule
abbreviation for hypertext transfer protocol: a set of instructions made by a computer program that allows your computer to connect to an internet document:
examples: http://www.cambridge.org

meanings.definition: abbreviation for hypertext transfer protocol: a set of instructions made by a computer program that allows your computer to connect to a website or internet document:
examples: The first part of a URL tells you the type of resource or method of access at that address; http, for example, takes you to a hypertext document or directory.

meanings.definition: the central or main part of something where there is most activity:
examples: The City of London is the hub of the UK's financial world.
The computer department is at the hub of the company's operations.

meanings.definition: the central part of a wheel into which the spokes (= bars connecting the central part to the outer edge of the wheel) are fixed
the central part of something, esp. of a wheel, or a center of activity:
examples: Chicago is a major transportation hub, with the busiest airport in the US.

meanings.definition: the central or main part of something, where there is most activity:
examples: Property rentals in Mumbai, India's commercial hub, are the highest in the world.
New Orleans has traditionally been the financial hub of southeast Louisiana.

meanings.definition: a machine that connects several computers together:
examples: an ethernet hub

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         hub airport
an airport with flights to lots of different places, where people can arrive from one city or country and get flights to other cities or countries:
examples: Passengers don't want to fly to a congested hub airport where they will then have to queue for another flight to their final destination.

meanings.definition: a transport system in which passengers travel from smaller airports, stations, etc. to one large central airport, station, etc. to make longer trips:
examples: The main disadvantage to a hub-and-spoke system is that any disruption at the hub, such as bad weather, can create delays.

meanings.definition: a type of squash (= a large vegetable with a hard skin and a lot of seeds inside) with green, orange, or blue skin:
examples: The blue variety of Hubbard squash is particularly impressive.
Try using a Hubbard squash in all recipes that require pumpkins.
Most Hubbard squash are huge, but this variety is the size of an orange.
There was a row of Hubbard squashes sown in the cornfield.

meanings.definition: a loud noise, especially caused by a lot of people all talking at the same time:
examples: I could hardly hear myself speak above all the hubbub in the bar.

meanings.definition: general excitement and activity:
examples: Once the hubbub of the election had died down, it was back to normal for the president.

meanings.definition: a mixture of continuing noises producing a feeling of busy activity or confused excitement:
examples: There is always quite a hubbub in the hallways between class periods when students are moving from one room to another.

meanings.definition: informal for husband:
examples: She speaks fondly of Richard Moreland, hubby number one, whom she still sees regularly.

meanings.definition: the circular metal covering over the hub of a vehicle's wheel
a round cover that fits over the center of the outside of a car’s wheel
a way of talking or behaving that is too proud:
examples: He was punished for his hubris.

meanings.definition: an extreme and unreasonable feeling of pride and confidence in yourself:
examples: Hubris brought him down in the end.

meanings.definition: too proud:
examples: He has a hubristic resistance to admitting he is wrong.

meanings.definition: a small, round, dark blue fruit, or the low North American bush on which it grows
a small, round, dark blue fruit, or the low North American bush on which it grows
a person who writes advertisements, especially for radio and television, or who sells things or brings ideas or people to the public's attention in a noisy, annoying way
a person who sells things or puts forward ideas in a very determined way that is often not completely honest

abbreviation for 
        
         head-up display   or heads-up display: in a vehicle, a special screen or an area of the windscreen where information such as speed is shown, and which the driver can see without having to look down:
examples: The HUD allows drivers to keep their eyes on the road while still viewing data such as speedometer readings and GPS directions.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for head-up display or heads-up display: in a computer game, the part of the screen that shows information such as the player's score, how much time they have left, etc., which the player can easily see while playing the game:
examples: Sometimes a game's HUD can be distracting.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for Department for Housing and Urban Development: a US government department that manages the building of low-cost houses and apartments and new building in cities:
examples: HUD is the agency responsible for encouraging housing development.

meanings.definition: to come close together in a group, for example because it is cold:
examples: Employees huddled round television sets at the company headquarters.
It was so cold that we huddled together for warmth.

meanings.definition: to sit or stand in a bent position with your arms and legs close to your body, especially because of cold or fear:
examples: Sophie was so frightened by the noise of the fireworks that she huddled (up) in a corner of the room.

meanings.definition: to discuss something privately in a small group:
examples: After huddling with advisors, the president gave a speech.
We spoke to Democratic lawmakers who are huddling on this issue on Capitol Hill tonight.

meanings.definition: a small group of people or things that are close together:
examples: A small group of people stood in a huddle at the bus stop.
The campsite comprises a huddle of tents on a bend in the river.

meanings.definition: a group formed by the members of a sports team in order to have a discussion, before they separate and continue to play:
examples: I called a huddle and said, "We're going to do something different this time."

meanings.definition: to come close together in a group, or to hold your arms and legs close to your body, esp. because of cold or fear:
examples: Everyone huddled around the fire to keep warm.

meanings.definition: standing or sitting close together:
examples: We stood huddled together for warmth.
Everyone was huddled around the radio listening to the news.

meanings.definition: sitting, lying, or standing in a bent position with your arms and legs close to your body, especially because of cold or fear:
examples: He sat in his tent, huddled under a blanket.

meanings.definition: discussing something privately in a small group:
examples: He has spent quite a bit of time huddled with senior officials talking about the situation.

meanings.definition: a large body of water in northern Canada that is part of the Arctic Ocean:
examples: Its purposes were to develop the fur trade around Hudson Bay and to search for the northwest passage.
Global warming means Hudson Bay is now open to shipping an extra week a year.

meanings.definition: (a degree of lightness, darkness, strength, etc. of) a colour:
examples: In the Caribbean waters there are fish of every hue.

meanings.definition: a different type or group:
examples: Politicians of all hues wish to get sleaze off the agenda so that they can discuss the real issues.

meanings.definition: a color, or the particular degree of light or dark of a color:
examples: In the waters of the Caribbean there are fish of every hue.

meanings.definition: a noisy expression of public anger or disapproval:
examples: There has been a great hue and cry about the council's plans to close the school.

meanings.definition: a dish, originally from Mexico, of fried eggs served with a spicy sauce on a tortilla (= a type of thin, round bread made from maize) and eaten for breakfast:
examples: They serve the most delicious huevos rancheros, accompanied by avocado and refried beans.
Mexican breakfasts are something else - you must try the huevos rancheros.

meanings.definition: an angry and offended mood:
examples: Ted's gone into one of his huffs again.

meanings.definition: to say something in an annoyed or offended way:
examples: "Well if that's how you feel, I'll go," she huffed.

meanings.definition: to breathe loudly, esp. after physical exercise:
examples: He huffed and puffed going up the stairs.

meanings.definition: to breathe loudly, usually after physical exercise: to complain loudly and express disapproval:
examples: We were huffing and puffing by the time we'd climbed to the top of the hill.
They huffed and puffed about the price but eventually they paid up.

meanings.definition: in an angry and offended way, especially when this is unreasonable:
examples: She warned huffily against compromising on critical issues.
"I didn't come here to talk about that," he said huffily.

to say something in an annoyed or offended way:

meanings.definition: angry and offended:

meanings.definition: to hold someone close to your body with your arms, usually to show that you like, love, or value them:
examples: Have you hugged your child today?
They hugged each other when they met at the station.
Emily hugged her teddy bear tightly to her chest.
She sat on the floor hugging her knees (= with her knees bent up against her chest and her arms around them).
Whenever I travel in the city I make sure I hug my handbag tightly to me.

meanings.definition: to stay very close to something or someone:
examples: The road hugs the coast for several miles, then turns inland.
This type of car will hug (= not slide on) the road, even in the wettest conditions.
a figure-hugging dress

meanings.definition: to keep something that makes you feel better or pleases you private or secret:
examples: I hugged the idea to myself all through dinner.

meanings.definition: the act of holding someone or something close to your body with your arms:
examples: Come here and give me a big hug.
We always exchange hugs and kisses when we meet.

meanings.definition: to hold someone or something close to your body with your arms, esp. to show affection:
examples: Maria hugged her dog.
As the verdict of not guilty was announced, he leaped up and hugged his lawyer.
fig. Some fish hug (= stay close to) the bottom of the lake.

meanings.definition: extremely large in size or amount:
examples: They live in a huge house.
The costs involved in building a spacecraft are huge.
A huge number of people attended.
His last three movies have all been huge successes.

meanings.definition: extremely large in size or amount:
examples: a huge forest
a huge parking lot
They made huge profits in real estate.

meanings.definition: to a great degree:
examples: He gave her a hugely expensive diamond ring.
Their business has been hugely successful.

meanings.definition: Someone or something that is huggable makes you want to hug him, her, or it:
examples: He's so huggable!

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         hug
someone who likes to express affection for someone (= liking them) in a physical way by hugging (= holding them close to your body with your arms):
examples: I'm not a hugger, but I was so happy I grabbed him and lifted him off the ground.
These people are huggers. They show more emotion than any other group of men I've ever met.

meanings.definition: in a confused, untidy way that lacks order:
examples: The paintings were hung hugger-mugger on the walls.
I grew up with eight siblings all living hugger-mugger.

meanings.definition: (of discussions, etc.) done in a secret way, without letting people know what is being said:
examples: Campaigners want to bring transparency to processes that currently are conducted hugger-mugger.

meanings.definition: confused or untidy and lacking order:
examples: The meeting was described as a hugger-mugger affair with no agenda, which soon descended into chaotic argument.

meanings.definition: talking to someone in a secret way:
examples: He was hugger-mugger with his deputy all morning.

meanings.definition: a place or situation that is confused or untidy and lacks order:
examples: The room is a hugger-mugger of tables.
The village is just a hugger-mugger of cottages clinging to the side of a mountain.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         hug
used to show that you have not heard or understood something:
examples: "So what do you want to do tonight?" "Huh? What did you say?"
Huh? These instructions don't make sense!

meanings.definition: used to express disapproval:
examples: Huh, I don't think much of that idea!

meanings.definition: used at the end of a question or statement, especially when you want someone to agree with what you have said:
examples: I'll bet you wish you hadn't done that, huh?
Pretty cool, huh?

meanings.definition: said to show that you have not heard or understood something, or used at the end of a statement to question it:
examples: "Huh? What did you say?"
"You called right in middle of dinner." "Great timing, huh?"

meanings.definition: a bush or small tree of the acacia family, found in America and grown in other places, with thorns (= sharp points) and groups of yellow flowers that are used to make perfume (= liquid with a pleasant smell, often used on the skin) because of their strong, pleasant smell:
examples: Huisache and prickly pear bloomed here then, just as they do now.
The green tops of mesquite and huisache trees dot the surface near the shore.

meanings.definition: a traditional dance from Hawaii, performed by dancers wearing grass skirts
a skirt made of long pieces of real or artificial grass, traditionally worn by dancers in the Hawaiian islands
a brand name for a large ring, usually made of plastic, that children play with by putting it around their waist and moving their body so that it spins
the body of an old ship, car, or very large piece of equipment that is broken and no longer used:
examples: Here and there the rusted hulk of an abandoned car dots the landscape.

meanings.definition: a large, heavy, awkward person or thing:
examples: Henry's a real hulk of a man.
The Incredible Hulk is a character in a comic who turns from a scientist into a two-metre tall monster.

meanings.definition: the body of an old ship, car, or large piece of equipment, which is broken and no longer used:
examples: The rusted hulk of an abandoned car sat at the side of the road.

meanings.definition: a large, heavy person or thing:
examples: He was a huge hulk of a man, about six and a half feet tall.

meanings.definition: large and heavy:
examples: We were stopped by two hulking security guards.
How do you expect me to lift that hulking great box?

meanings.definition: the body or frame of a ship, most of which goes under the water
to remove the covering or the stem and leaves from some fruits, vegetables, and seeds:
examples: We sat in the garden hulling strawberries.

meanings.definition: a city in northeast England whose full name is Kingston upon Hull :
examples: They would travel to Hamburg, then by boat to Hull .
We lived in Hull for 17 years.

meanings.definition: the body or frame of a ship, most of which lies under the water
the outer covering of a seed or fruit, such as the shell of a nut
a loud noise made by people who are angry or annoyed; a lot of angry comments made in public about someone or something:
examples: There's a crowd of angry demonstrators making a real hullabaloo outside the Houses of Parliament.

meanings.definition: public disapproval or complaints:
examples: The minister resigned after all the hullabaloo over his affair with an actress.

meanings.definition: a loud noise made by people, often because they are angry, or a situation in which many people are angry or upset:
examples: They finally stopped production of the play because of all the hullabaloo it caused.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         hull
to remove the covering or the stem and leaves from some fruits, vegetables, and seeds:
examples: We sat in the garden hulling strawberries.

meanings.definition: dried that has been made soft in water, or water and lye (= a chemical) in order to remove the hard outer part of the grain:
examples: You need to soak the corn kernels for a long time before boiling them to make hulled corn.
Hulled corn is just another name for hominy.

         hull
to remove the covering or the stem and leaves from some fruits, vegetables, and seeds:
examples: We sat in the garden hulling strawberries.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         hello
to make a continuous low sound:
examples: The computers were humming in the background.
What's that strange humming sound?

meanings.definition: to sing without opening your mouth:
examples: She hummed to herself as she walked to school.
I've forgotten how that song goes - could you hum it for me?

meanings.definition: to be busy and full of activity, excitement, sounds, or voices:
examples: The bar was really humming last night.

meanings.definition: to smell very unpleasant:
examples: Your feet really hum!

meanings.definition: a continuous low noise:
examples: Our house is on a main road, so we can hear the constant hum of traffic.
There's an annoying hum on this computer.

meanings.definition: to make a continuous, low sound, or to sing a tune with closed lips:
examples: Debbie always hums to herself when she listens to music.
I’ve forgotten how that tune goes – could you hum it for me?

meanings.definition: fig. If something is humming, it is very busy and full of activity:
examples: Factories that make paper products are humming at 97% of capacity.

meanings.definition: a continuous, low sound:
examples: We could hear the constant hum of traffic outside the window.

meanings.definition: to be uncertain and take a long time deciding something:
examples: We hummed and hawed for months before actually deciding to buy the house.

meanings.definition: being, relating to, or belonging to a person or to people as opposed to animals:
examples: The human body is composed of about 60 percent water.
They found some remains which were thought to be human.
Victory in the war was achieved at the cost of great human suffering.
The inspector declared the meat fit for human consumption (= in good enough condition for people to eat).

meanings.definition: having the qualities, faults, and feelings that people have, as opposed to gods, animals, or machines:
examples: Of course I make mistakes, I'm only human.
When he laughs it makes him seem more human.
It's very human to have regrets about the past.

meanings.definition: a person:
examples: The greatest damage being done to our planet today is that being done by humans.

meanings.definition: of or typical of people:
examples: the human body
Of course I make mistakes, I’m only human (= not perfect).
The accident was due to human error (= a person’s mistake).

meanings.definition: relating to people:
examples: Most of the problems were caused by human error, poor communication and staffing issues.
The new regulations would improve labour conditions and protect human welfare.

meanings.definition: a person:
examples: Industrial waste can pose a serious threat to humans and the environment.

meanings.definition: a person
employees, and all of the knowledge, skills, experience, etc. that they have, which makes them valuable to a company or economy:
examples: The corporation has become so valuable, not because of its fixed assets, but because of the human capital of its software engineers and programmers.

meanings.definition: a measurement of the development of a country that is based on the health, education, and standard of living of the people who live there:
examples: It ranks 160th out of 172 nations in/on the human development index.
Cyprus is an advanced, high-income economy with a very high Human Development Index.

meanings.definition: a mistake made by a person:
examples: Many of the problems were the result of human error.
The reason for the disaster was engine failure, not human error.

meanings.definition: the act of studying how people use systems or equipment in order to design, develop, and create technology that is safer, more effective, etc.:
examples: Human Factors Engineering is used to improve patient safety by applying what is known about human capabilities and limitations when evaluating products or processes.

meanings.definition: an attempt to discover all the genetic information in the human body
the study of the different ways in which human societies develop and operate in relation to their physical environment
the virus that causes AIDS (= a serious disease that destroys the body's ability to fight infection)
details about people's experiences and feelings:
examples: I like newspapers with lots of human interest stories in them.

meanings.definition: the natural ways of behaving that most people share:
examples: You can't change human nature.
It's only human nature (= it is natural) to want the best for your children.

meanings.definition: the behavior and feelings common to most people
relationships between groups of people, especially between workers in a place of work, or the study of these relationships
the relationships between groups of people, especially between different workers in an organization or business:
examples: Through trust and collaboration we are able to build good human relations in the workplace.

meanings.definition: the study of the relationships between groups of people in an organization or business, or a system used for improving these relationships:
examples: Human relations training is required by law for any person seeking certification in the state.

meanings.definition: people, when considered as an asset that is or can be employed and that is useful to a company, organization, etc.:
examples: Over 50% of the city's unemployed residents are a viable human resource for employment.
Companies must invest in both technology and human resources if they hope to secure a stable and competitive future.

meanings.definition: relating to people when they are considered as an asset to a company, etc., or relating to a human resources department :
examples: a new human resource strategy
We must consider the human resource implications of this decision.
A human resource assistant is urgently required to provide administrative support for our busy HR department.

meanings.definition: the job of helping employees develop their skills and knowledge, especially by training them:
examples: They aim to improve labour productivity through human resource development.

meanings.definition: a type of software that is used by a company's human resources department for managing records and information about their employees:
examples: You can customize your Human Resources Information System to track pay rises, positions held, and performance development plans.

meanings.definition: the activity of managing a company’s employees, for example, by employing new workers, training them, managing their employment records, and helping them with problems:
examples: Research shows that human resource management plays a huge role in how successfully a company performs.

meanings.definition: the process by which an organization makes sure that it has the right managers and employees to achieve its objectives:
examples: Having the capacity to understand the dynamics of international labour becomes crucial to strategic human resource planning, recruitment, and selection.

meanings.definition: the department of an organization that deals with finding new employees, keeping records about all the organization's employees, and helping them with any problems
the department within a company or organization that is responsible for its relationship with its employees and for following employment laws
a person who in charge of the department that deals with the employment, training, support, records, etc. of a company's employees:
examples: The human resource manager is also responsible for writing up job descriptions.

meanings.definition: a basic right that it is generally agreed that all people should have, for example justice or the freedom to say what you think:
examples: She's claiming that her detention by the police was a violation of her human rights.
I believe that it is a human right to get an education.
The human rights activist has been in detention since February.

meanings.definition: the basic rights to fair and moral treatment that every person is believed to have
a person or group of people kept in a particular place in order to stop an enemy from attacking that place:
examples: Military bases were protected by captured enemy soldiers who were housed there as a human shield.

meanings.definition: the crime of buying and selling people, or making money from work they are forced to do, such as sex work:
examples: International organized crime includes human trafficking, drug running and money laundering.

meanings.definition: used to describe computers, technology, systems, etc. that are designed to work in ways that people can easily understand and learn:
examples: human-centered design/engineering/computing

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         humanistic  :
examples: They decided to take a more human-centered approach.

meanings.definition: showing kindness, care, and sympathy towards others, especially those who are suffering:
examples: The humane way of dealing with a suffering animal (= the way that causes the least pain) is to kill it quickly.

meanings.definition: showing kindness, care, and sympathy toward others, esp. those who are suffering:
examples: She felt it was more humane to kill the injured animal quickly than to let it suffer.

meanings.definition: in a way that is humane (= showing kindness, care, and sympathy):
examples: I don't support the death penalty, but if people are to be executed, it should be done humanely.
The authorities wanted a guarantee that the prisoners would be treated humanely.

meanings.definition: a belief system based on the principle that people's spiritual and emotional needs can be satisfied without following a god or religion
a system of thought and reasoning based on human values and interests, often without accepting the beliefs of religion
a person who believes in humanism (= the idea that people do not need a god or religion to satisfy their spiritual and emotional needs):
examples: She is a liberal and a humanist.
I respected him as a man of exceptional moral stature and a humanist.

meanings.definition: relating to or believing in humanism (= the idea that people do not need a god or religion to satisfy their spiritual and emotional needs):
examples: Both men come from a humanist tradition.

meanings.definition: relating to humanism (= the idea that people do not need a god or religion to satisfy their spiritual and emotional needs):
examples: Humanistic philosophy affirms that knowledge and power come from people and from the nature in which they live.
humanistic principles

meanings.definition: treating people with respect and making certain they are safe, happy, healthy, etc.:
examples: Using a humanistic approach to deal with employees can help ease workplace tensions and anxieties.

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to humanism (= the idea that people do not need a god or religion to satisfy their spiritual and emotional needs):
examples: The need to address these events in a humanistically meaningful way has become even more important.
I think this is a humanistically and morally valid viewpoint.

meanings.definition: (a person who is) involved in or connected with improving people's lives and reducing suffering:
examples: The prisoner has been released for humanitarian reasons.
The United Nations is sending humanitarian aid (= food and supplies to help people) to the areas worst affected by the conflict.
The well-known humanitarian, Joseph Rowntree, was concerned with the welfare of his employees.

meanings.definition: involved in or connected with improving people’s lives and reducing suffering:
examples: humanitarian aid in the form of food supplies

meanings.definition: an international set of rules that try to limit the effects of war:
examples: Every government is obliged under international humanitarian law to protect the civilian population during military operations.
The rebels' leader faced 17 charges, including crimes against humanity and violations of humanitarian law.

meanings.definition: a belief in improving people's lives and reducing suffering:
examples: The doctors’ mission is motivated by humanitarianism.
The students pride themselves on their humanitarianism.

meanings.definition: a plant or animal that has been produced from two different types of plant or animal

meanings.definition: to produce something new from two other different things, that has features of both the things:

meanings.definition: a way of speaking or writing that makes someone or something sound much bigger, better, smaller, worse, more unusual, etc., than they are:

meanings.definition: extremely critical (= too eager to find mistakes in everything)
(of a disease) extremely common in a particular area or amongst a particular group of people :
examples: Most adults in areas of hyperendemic malaria have immunity to the disease.
Malaria was hyper-endemic by the beach, so the village had been built on the cliffs above it.

meanings.definition: a state in which there are very strong reactions to stimuli (= things that cause a physical reaction):
examples: Hyperexcitability caused by steroid use could be evidence of impaired brain function.
Use of this medication in children may cause hyper-excitability and nightmares.

meanings.definition: reacting very strongly to stimuli (= things that cause a physical reaction):
examples: People who are unfortunate enough to have migraines have cells in their brains that are hyperexcitable.
Patients with alcohol withdrawal present with a hyper-excitable state.

meanings.definition: a condition where someone excretes (= gets rid of) more of a substance from the body than is normal or usual:
examples: Such hyperexcretion was also manifested in patients with metastatic disease in which the primary tumour had been removed.
mucous hyper-excretion

meanings.definition: the extension (= stretching) of a body part beyond normal or safe limits, or an occasion when someone does this:
examples: The most common injury was hyperextension of the middle finger.
Hyperextensions and hyperflexions can result in damage to the joints.

meanings.definition: a condition where a part of the body is unusually active or too active:
examples: Adrenal gland hyperfunction causes excessive production of one or more adrenal hormones.
These compounds may be useful in treating the diseases caused by hyper-function of human immunity.

meanings.definition: A hyperfunctioning part of the body is unusually active or too active:
examples: Hyperfunctioning thyroid nodules are usually benign but may sometimes be malignant.
The study provided evidence that these autoreceptors may be hyperfunctional in depressed patients.

meanings.definition: a condition in which there is too much glucose in the blood:
examples: Hyperglycaemia is the defining characteristic of diabetes mellitus.

meanings.definition: a condition in which there is too much glucose in the blood:
examples: Hyperglycemia is the defining characteristic of diabetes mellitus.

meanings.definition: a condition in which a person produces much more sweat (= a salty liquid passed through the skin) than normal:
examples: The first step in treating hyperhidrosis is to determine whether there is an underlying condition causing the excessive sweating.

meanings.definition: (of prices or the value of something) very high and increasing quickly in an uncontrolled way:
examples: The hyperinflated cost of property in the area means that young adults are struggling to buy their first home.
Despite its hyper-inflated worth on the stock market, the company has stuck steadfastly to its core values.

meanings.definition: (of a market) having prices that are very high and increasing quickly in an uncontrolled way :
examples: California's energy market has been hyperinflated for some time.

meanings.definition: (of a lung or part of a lung) much larger than is normal or usual because there is air inside that cannot escape:
examples: The chest x-ray shows evidence of hyperinflated lungs.
He took an X-ray and said her lungs were hyper-inflated.

meanings.definition: a condition where the price of everything in a national economy goes out of control and increases very quickly
a situation in which prices are rising extremely fast:
examples: Economists generally reserve the term “hyperinflation” for cases when the monthly inflation rate reaches over 50 percent.

meanings.definition: extremely and unusually intense (= strong, forceful, or serious):
examples: He is a typical hyper-intense, hyper-passionate American college kid.
She has the hyperintense focus of true obsession.

meanings.definition: a condition in which there is too much potassium in the blood, which may be caused by diuretics (= substances that increase the production of urine) having been used too often or kidney failure
a condition in which there is too much potassium in the blood, which may be caused by diuretics (= substances that increase the production of urine) having been used too often or kidney failure
a connection that allows you to move easily between two computer documents or two pages on the internet
a word, phrase, or image on a website or in a computer document which you click on in order to go to a different website, different part of the document, etc.:
examples: Brokerage websites will often provide a hyperlink to the broker's internet trading area.

meanings.definition: to connect to another page, image, document, etc. on a website or computer document by creating a hyperlink:
examples: To hyperlink directly to a page in a PDF you must add an open parameter to the end of the URL.

meanings.definition: a state of unusually extreme physical and mental activity, often involving a loss of judgment and feelings of great and unreasonable happiness:
examples: The patient was suffering from hypermania and had a history of mental illness.
The list of precautions says that the drug can cause activation of mania or hyper-mania.

meanings.definition: experiencing a state of unusually extreme physical and mental activity, often involving a loss of judgment and feelings of great and unreasonable happiness:
examples: He has been variously diagnosed as depressive, hypermanic, and bipolar.
The psychiatric report described him as bipolar, suffering from attention-deficit disorder, and possibly hyper-manic.

meanings.definition: a very large shop, usually outside the centre of town
a very large store that is a type of supermarket and that is usually built outside of the centre of a town, selling food and other products such as clothes, furniture, and goods for the home:
examples: The supermarket chain, which already owns hypermarkets in Eastern Europe, Thailand, Korea and Taiwan, is looking to open in Malaysia.

meanings.definition: a combination of videos, images, sounds, text, etc. that are connected together on a website, which you can click on in order to use them or to go to other related videos, websites, etc.:
examples: Hypermedia enables us to link text to text, text to image, and image to image, on both a macro and micro level.

meanings.definition: typical of, or showing, unusually high metabolic activity (= the chemical processes within the body required for life):
examples: Carbohydrates are usually the primary source of non-protein calories during the hypermetabolic state.
In most patients, hyper-metabolic symptoms diminish 6 to 8 weeks after treatment.

meanings.definition: unusually high metabolic activity (= the chemical processes within the body required for life):
examples: The child may have a good appetite but does not gain weight because of hypermetabolism.

meanings.definition: a condition in which someone can see things clearly that are far away but not things that are near:
examples: In hypermetropia, rays of light coming from a distance are focused behind the retina.

meanings.definition: to use particular driving methods in order to use as little fuel as possible:
examples: Check our website for tips on how to hypermile.

meanings.definition: someone who uses particular driving methods in order to use as little fuel as possible:
examples: You can become a hypermiler, fill your tyres to the optimal level, and take advantage of tax breaks for hybrid drivers.

meanings.definition: the use of particular driving methods in order to use as little fuel as possible:
examples: He claims that hypermiling helps his car get 60 miles per gallon on a regular basis.

meanings.definition: able to move and bend the body's joints (= places where bones join such as in your fingers, at your knees, etc.) more than is usual:
examples: The child has low muscle tone and hypermobile joints but she is getting stronger all the time.
Patients are considered hypermobile if they score 4 or more out of 9 on the test.

meanings.definition: a condition in which someone is able to move and bend their joints (= places where bones join such as in your fingers, at your knees, etc.) more than is usual:
examples: This is a genetic condition affecting collagen (a basic building block of the body), which then causes hypermobility of the joints.
For most children these muscle cramps are due to hypermobility - excessive suppleness or being "double-jointed".

meanings.definition: extremely modern:
examples: The restaurant's interior as well as its food is hypermodern, with walls of wine bottles displayed behind glass.
Hyper-modern residential tower blocks overlook the harbour, dwarfing the older buildings.

meanings.definition: the ability of cells to mutate (= change permanently) much faster than usual, or the state or condition of doing this:
examples: Her research is in the area of hypermutability in carcinogenesis.

meanings.definition: Hypermutable cells mutate (= change permanently) much more quickly than usual:

meanings.definition: a word whose meaning includes a group of other words:

meanings.definition: a condition in which someone can see things clearly that are far away but not things that are near:
examples: Focusing the telescope corrects any myopia or hyperopia automatically.

meanings.definition: a rare genetic disorder in which there is too much oxalate (= an organic salt) in the urine so that calcium oxalate crystals form in the kidneys and kidney stones are produced
not limited or ruled by physical limits or laws:
examples: He suggested that the human mind exists on some sort of hyperphysical level.

meanings.definition: the fact of some areas of skin being darker than others, often caused by skin damage or certain medical conditions :
examples: Hyperpigmentation may be caused by certain drugs.

meanings.definition: Hyperpigmented skin has areas that are darker than others or darker than usual:

meanings.definition: an abnormal increase in the number of cells in a body tissue or organ:
examples: Benign prostatic hyperplasia is an increase in size of the prostate.

meanings.definition: the production of much greater amounts of something than is usual or normal:
examples: Three of the subjects in the study had lactic acid hyperproduction following physical exercise.

meanings.definition: reacting very strongly to physical stimuli (= things that cause a reaction):
examples: Asthma attacks are caused by hyperreactive airways.

meanings.definition: a condition in which someone reacts very strongly to stimuli (= things that cause reaction):
examples: Evidence of bronchial hyper-reactivity was obtained in 113 patients.

meanings.definition: showing a very strong response (= reaction) to stimuli (= things that cause a reaction) :

meanings.definition: extremely romantic or too romantic:

meanings.definition: containing a lot of salt or too much salt:

meanings.definition: the production of too much saliva (= liquid) in the mouth:

meanings.definition: the production of too much of a liquid in the body:

meanings.definition: too easily upset by criticism:

meanings.definition: very easily influenced, changed, or damaged, especially by a physical activity or effect:

meanings.definition: very easily changed or damaged by physical conditions, or easily upset:

meanings.definition: a condition in which the immune system reacts in an extreme way to a substance in the body:

meanings.definition: a sleep disorder in which someone sleeps for very long periods and is always very tired during the day

meanings.definition: to make something such as a part of the body or an economy become very active or too active:

meanings.definition: a situation in which something such as a part of the body or an economy becomes very active or too active:

meanings.definition: extremely tense (= nervous, worried, and unable to relax):

meanings.definition: a condition in which a person worries a lot about their health without having a good reason to do so:

meanings.definition: a situation in which someone pretends to believe something that they do not really believe, or that is the opposite of what they do or say at another time:

examples: Several hypotheses for global warming have been suggested.

meanings.definition: an idea or explanation for something that may be true but has not yet been completely proved:
examples: Evidence supports their hypothesis that a long-term relationship built on trust and obligation between a buyer and a sub-contractor leads to prompt delivery and better cooperation.

meanings.definition: to give a possible but not yet proved explanation for something:
examples: We hypothesized that children of alcoholic fathers will demonstrate more behavioural problems.
There's no point hypothesizing about how the accident happened, since we'll never really know.
This discovery led experts to hypothesize a different path of evolution for early man.

meanings.definition: to give a possible but not yet proven explanation for something:
examples: There's no point hypothesizing about how the accident happened, since we'll never really know.

past simple and past participle of 
        
         hypothesize

meanings.definition: imagined or suggested but not necessarily real or true:
examples: a hypothetical example/situation
This is all very hypothetical but supposing Jackie got the job, how would that affect you?

meanings.definition: of or based on a hypothesis:
examples: He dismissed the questions as purely hypothetical.

meanings.definition: imagined or suggested, but perhaps not true or really happening:
examples: Total return will be based on a hypothetical $1,000 investment.

meanings.definition: in a way that is imagined or suggested but not necessarily real or true:
examples: Any electronic voting system is hypothetically hackable.
Hypothetically speaking, caffeine does affect circulation.

meanings.definition: relating to a method of research (= a detailed study of a subject, especially in order to discover new information) in which you begin with a theory, and then do tests to see if it is correct or not :
examples: Many scientists would argue that good science is based on the hypothetico-deductive method.
This methodology corresponds with the hypothetico-deductive model of science, where a hypothesis is tested by observation.

meanings.definition: a condition in which the thyroid gland does not produce enough thyroid hormone, leading to heart problems, problems with nerve function in the hands and feet, and mental health issues such as depression:
examples: Muscular hypertrophy is one of the signs of hypothyroidism.

meanings.definition: a condition in which there is not enough oxygen available to the blood and body tissues:
examples: Doctors are learning more about the threat that affects every airline passenger: hypoxia, the term for too little oxygen.
After major surgery hypoxia can occur for up to for 3 days, particularly at night.

meanings.definition: a situation in which there is not enougth oxygen in a place or environment:
examples: His team studied fish in an estuary suffering hypoxia.
Hypoxia is an oxygen deficiency in water that threatens the survival of many species.

meanings.definition: caused by not enough oxygen being available to the blood and body tissues:
examples: He died of hypoxic encephalopathy - a lack of oxygen to the brain, following cardiac arrest.
The degree of hypoxic stress depends on altitude, rate of ascent, and duration of exposure.

meanings.definition: (of a place or environment) not having enough oxygen:
examples: A hypoxic zone is an area of low oxygen that forms in coastal waters.
A hypoxic environment may be deliberately sought by endurance athletes who try to naturally increase their oxygen transport capacity.

meanings.definition: relating to hypsometry (= the science of measuring the high and low areas of the Earth's surface):
examples: A clear indication that there is no global system of plate tectonics on Venus is its hypsometric distribution.
A hypsometric curve shows the elevations of the regions lying between the continental platforms and the ocean basins.

meanings.definition: the science of measuring the high and low areas of the earth's surface:
examples: The research findings contain detailed analyses of continental hypsometry.
This reasoning involves assumptions about present-day hypsometry.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for"have your say": a place on a website, especially a news website, where users can write their opinions:
examples: The story is no longer marked as having an HYS attached to it.
Some of the comments on the website's HYS are unbelievably stupid.

meanings.definition: a kind of green tea from China:
examples: When you add hot water to hyson, the dried leaves start to unfurl.
Hyson tea comes from Anhui province in eastern China.

meanings.definition: a small bush that has small blue or pink flowers and thin leaves with a strong smell, used in cooking, traditional medicine, and to make perfume (= a liquid with a pleasant smell) :
examples: She grows extra flowers such as zinnias and hyssop for the bees at her farm.
Local growers bring herbs like wood sorrel and hyssop to the restaurant three times a week.

meanings.definition: a plant mentioned in the Bible, used in religious ceremonies :
examples: The hyssop of the Bible is thought to be either marjoram or the caper plant.
A plant referred to as hyssop appears repeatedly in the Old Testament.

meanings.definition: a medical operation to remove part or all of a woman's womb
a medical operation to remove part or all of a woman’s uterus
the situation where changes in one part of the economy take time to have an effect on other parts:
examples: Hysteresis effects arising from the recession include long-term unemployment and drops in productivity levels.

meanings.definition: extreme fear, excitement, anger, etc. that cannot be controlled:
examples: One woman, close to hysteria, grabbed my arm.
Tabloid hysteria about the murders has increased public fears.
mass hysteria

meanings.definition: excitement or emotion that is uncontrollable:
examples: One woman, close to hysteria, grabbed my arm.

meanings.definition: unable to control your feelings or behaviour because you are extremely frightened, angry, excited, etc.:
examples: Calm down, you're getting hysterical.
The police were accused of hysterical over-reaction.
hysterical laughter (= uncontrolled laughter)

meanings.definition: extremely funny:
examples: His last film was hysterical.

meanings.definition: unable to control your emotions or behavior because you are very frightened, excited, etc.:
examples: Calm down, you’re getting hysterical.
She broke into hysterical laughter (= laughter that is uncontrollable).
infml That joke was hysterical (= extremely amusing).

meanings.definition: without being able to control your feelings or behaviour because you are extremely frightened, angry, excited, etc.:
examples: She started laughing/crying hysterically.
He had become hysterically volatile, laughing one moment and crying the next.

meanings.definition: extremely funny:
examples: He's one of the most hysterically funny people I've ever met.
The book is both hysterically funny and poignantly sad.
Her impressions of the teachers were hysterically funny.
I'd forgotten how hysterically funny her brother was.
They seemed to find our discomfort hysterically funny.

meanings.definition: uncontrolled behaviour or crying, usually caused by extreme fear or sadness:
examples: Convinced the plane was about to crash, many people were sobbing and in hysterics.

meanings.definition: uncontrolled laughter:
examples: He was hilarious - he had us all in hysterics.

meanings.definition: a state of uncontrollable excitement or emotion:
examples: I told her she couldn’t have it and she went into hysterics.

meanings.definition: a long thin tube with a small camera at the end, used in medical examinations of a woman's uterus (= the part of the body in which a baby grows):
examples: The hysteroscope is inserted through the cervix to reveal the inside of the uterus.
The hysteroscope has a small light and camera lens at its tip, which sends pictures from the inside of the womb to a video screen.

meanings.definition: a medical examination of a woman's uterus (= the part of the body in which a baby grows) using a long, thin tube:
examples: It usually takes between 10 and 60 minutes to perform a hysteroscopy.
Hysteroscopy was successful in locating the lesion.

written abbreviation for
        
         hertz
abbreviation for hertz
